→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: '''Winchester''' is a [[City status in the United Kingdom
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: city]] and the [[county town]] of [[Hampshire]], [[England]]. The city lies at the heart of the wider [[City of Winchester]], a local government [[Districts of England
column3: district]], at the western end of the [[South Downs]] National Park, on the [[River Itchen, Hampshire
column17: 0}} from [[Southampton]], the closest other city. At the 2011 Census, Winchester had a population of 45,184. The wider City of Winchester district, which includes towns such as [[New Alresford
column18: Alresford]] and [[Bishop's Waltham]], has a population of 116,595.<ref name=\"2011urbanarea\">{{cite web
column20: title=2011 Census: KS101EW Usual resident population, local authorities in England and Wales

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Roman]] town of [[Venta Belgarum]], which in turn developed from an [[Iron Age]] [[oppidum]]. Winchester's major landmark is [[Winchester Cathedral]], one of the largest cathedrals in Europe, with the distinction of having the longest nave and overall length of all [[Gothic architecture
column3: Gothic]] cathedrals in Europe. The city is home to the [[University of Winchester]] and [[Winchester College]], the oldest public school in the United Kingdom still using its original buildings.{{citation needed

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The area around Winchester has been inhabited since [[Prehistoric Britain
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: prehistoric times]], with three [[British Iron Age
column5: St. Catherine's Hill]], and Worthy Down all nearby. In the [[Late Iron Age]], a more urban settlement type developed, known as an ''[[oppidum]]'', although the archaeology of this phase remains obscure. It was overrun by the confederation of [[Gauls
column7: tribes]] known as the [[Belgae]] sometime in the 1st century BCE. It seems to have been known as '''Wentā''' or '''Venta''', derived from the [[Common Brittonic
column8: Brittonic]] for \"town\" or \"meeting place\",<ref>Matasović, Ranko. [http://iedo.brillonline.nl/dictionaries/lemma.html?id=17429 \"wentā\" in the ''Etymological Dictionary of Proto-Celtic'' at ''Indo-European Etymological Dictionaries Online''. Brill Online, 2014. Accessed 24 July 2014.]{{dead link
column11: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> or the word for \"white\" ([[Welsh language
column12: Welsh]] ''gwyn''), due to Winchester's situation upon chalk.<ref>{{cite book
column15: title=Observations Upon Certain Roman Roads and Towns in the South of Britain

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: After the [[Roman conquest of Britain]], the settlement served as the capital ({{lang-la
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: civitas}}) of the Belgae and was distinguished as '''Venta Belgarum''', \"Venta of the Belgae\". Although in the early years of the Roman province it was of subsidiary importance to [[Silchester Roman Town
column4: Chichester]], Venta eclipsed them both by the latter half of the second century.<ref>Cunliffe B. ''Wessex to AD 1000'' 1997</ref> At the beginning of the third century, Winchester was given protective stone walls.<ref>{{cite web
column9: accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref> At around this time the city covered an area of {{convert
column11: acres}}, making it among the largest towns in Roman Britain by surface area.<ref name=\"Roman towns\">{{cite web
column15: accessdate=18 June 2014}}</ref> There was a limited suburban area outside the walls.<ref>{{cite web
column18: accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref> Like many other Roman towns however, Winchester began to decline in the later fourth century.<ref name=\"Roman towns\"/><ref>{{cite web

column3: Statue of [[Alfred the Great]] by [[Hamo Thornycroft]] in Winchester]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: After the [[Roman withdrawal from Britain]] in 410, urban life seems to have continued at Venta Belgarum until around 450, and a small administrative centre might have continued after that on the site of the later Anglo-Saxon palace. [[David Nash Ford
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Ford]] identifies the community as the {{nowrap
column12: Fort]] Venta\") is listed by [[Nennius]] among the 28 cities of [[Sub-Roman Britain
column14: History of the Britons]]''.<ref name=nashford>Ford, David Nash. \"[http://www.britannia.com/history/ebk/articles/nenniuscities.html The 28 Cities of Britain] {{Webarchive
column16: date=15 April 2016 }}\" at Britannia. 2000.</ref> Amid the [[Saxon invasions of Britain]], cemeteries dating to the 6th and 7th centuries suggest a revival of settlement.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: [[File:Anglo-Saxon Chronicle - Wintan ceastre (British Library Cotton MS Tiberius A VI, folio 12r).jpg
column4: A mention of Wintan-ceastre in the ''Anglo-Saxon Chronicle'']]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The city became known as '''Wintan-ceastre''' (\"Fort Venta\") in [[Old English]].<ref name=\"Anglo-Saxon Dictionary\">{{cite web
column6: accessdate=18 June 2014}}</ref> In 648, [[King Cenwalh of Wessex
column8: Wessex]] erected the Church of SS Peter and Paul, later known as the [[Old Minster, Winchester
column9: Old Minster]]. This became a cathedral in the 660s when the West Saxon bishopric was transferred from [[Dorchester-on-Thames]]. The present form of the city dates from reconstruction in the late 9th century, when [[Alfred the Great
column10: King Alfred the Great]] obliterated the Roman street plan in favour of a new grid in order to provide better defence against the [[Viking invasions of Britain
column11: Vikings]]. The city's first mint appears to date from this period.<ref name=WB>{{cite encyclopedia
column12: encyclopedia=The Wiley Blackwell Encyclopaedia of Anglo-Saxon England

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In the early 10th century there were two new ecclesiastical establishments: the convent of [[Nunnaminster]], founded by Alfred's widow [[Ealhswith]],<ref>*{{cite encyclopedia
column6: encyclopedia= Oxford Dictionary of National Biography
column12: New Minster]]. Bishop [[Æthelwold of Winchester]] was a leading figure in the monastic reform movement of the later 10th century. He expelled the secular canons of both minsters and replaced them with monks. He created the drainage system, the \"Lockburn\", which served as the town drain until 1875, and still survives. Also in the late 10th century, the Old Minster was enlarged as a centre of the cult of the 9th century [[Bishop of Winchester]], Saint [[Swithun]]. The three minsters were the home of what architectural historian John Crook describes as \"the supreme artistic achievements\" of the ''Winchester School''.<ref name=WB/>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The consensus among historians of Anglo-Saxon England is that the court was mobile in this period and there was no fixed capital.<ref>{{cite book
column14: title=Æthelstan: the first king of England
column22: title=Citadel of the Saxons: The Rise of Early London
column27: isbn=978-1-3501-3568-0}}</ref> [[Martin Biddle]] has suggested that Winchester was a centre for royal administration in the 7th and 8th centuries, but this is questioned by [[Barbara Yorke]], who sees it as significant that the shire was named after Hamtun, the forerunner of [[Southampton]].<ref>{{cite journal
column31: journal=Proceedings of the Hampshire Field Club and Archaeological Society
column32: title=The Foundation of the Old Minster and the Status of Winchester in the Seventh and Eighth Centuries
column36: issn= 0142-8950}}</ref> However, Winchester is described by the historian Catherine Cubitt as \"the premier city of the West Saxon kingdom\"<ref>{{cite book
column41: title=A Companion to the Early Middle Ages: Britain and Ireland c.500- c.1100
column47: isbn=978-1-118-42513-8}}</ref> and [[Janet Nelson]] describes London and Winchester as Alfred the Great's \"proto-capitals\".<ref>{{cite book
column50: chapter=Power and authority at the Court of Alfred
column55: title= Essays on Anglo-Saxon and Related Themes in Memory of Lynne Grundy
column59: publisher=King's College London Centre for Late Antique & Medieval Studies

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: There was a fire in the city in 1141 during the [[Rout of Winchester]]. Much later, [[William of Wykeham]] played a role in the city's restoration. As [[Bishop of Winchester]] he was responsible for much of the current structure of the cathedral, and he founded the still extant public school [[Winchester College]]. During the [[Middle Ages]], the city was an important centre of the wool trade, before going into a slow decline.{{Citation needed
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: date=August 2016}} The [[curfew bell]] in the bell tower (near the clock in the picture), still sounds at 8:00 pm each evening.

column3: Winchester High Street in the mid 19th century.]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Jews lived in Winchester from at least 1148, and in the 13th century the Jewish community in the city was one of the most important in England. There was an [[Archa (document store)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: archa]] in the city, and the Jewish quarter was located in the city's heart (present day Jewry street). There were a series of [[blood libel]] claims against the Jewish community in the 1220s and 1230s, which likely was the cause of the hanging of the community's leader, Abraham Pinch, in front of the synagogue of which he was the head. [[Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester
column3: Simon de Montfort]] ransacked the Jewish quarter in 1264, and in 1290 all Jews were [[Edict of Expulsion
column7: publisher=The Museum of the Jewish People at Beit Hatfutsot

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The City Cross (also known as the [[Buttercross]]) has been dated to the 15th century, and features 12 statues of the [[Virgin Mary]], other saints and various historical figures. Several statues appear to have been added throughout the structure's history. In 1770, [[Thomas Dummer]] purchased the Buttercross from the Corporation of Winchester, intending to have it re-erected at [[Cranbury Park]], near [[Otterbourne]]. When his workmen arrived to dismantle the cross, they were prevented from doing so by the people of the city, who \"organised a small riot\",<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate= 23 September 2009}}</ref> and they were forced to abandon their task. The agreement with the city was cancelled and Dummer erected a [[lath and plaster]] facsimile, which stood in the park for about sixty years before it was destroyed by the weather.<ref name = \"Yonge8\">{{cite web
column15: authorlink = Charlotte M. Yonge}}</ref> The Buttercross itself was restored by [[George Gilbert Scott]] in 1865, and still stands in the High Street. It is now a [[Scheduled Ancient Monument]].<ref>{{cite web
column16: title= City Cross or 'Butter Cross', Winchester

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Three notable bronze sculptures can be seen in or from the High Street by major sculptors of the 19th and 20th centuries, the earliest a monumental statue of [[Queen Victoria]], now in the [[Great Hall]], by [[Sir Alfred Gilbert]] (also known as the sculptor of '[[Eros]]' in London's Piccadilly Circus), [[King Alfred]], facing the city with raised sword from the centre of The Broadway, by [[Hamo Thornycroft]] and the modern striking ''[[Horse and Rider (Frink)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Horse and Rider]]'' by [[Dame Elizabeth Frink]] at the entrance to the Law Courts.

column6: date=14 November 2011}}</ref> While staying in Winchester from mid-August to October 1819, the Romantic poet [[John Keats]] wrote \"Isabella\", \"St. Agnes' Eve\", \"[[To Autumn]]\", \"Lamia\" and parts of \"[[Hyperion (poem)
column7: Hyperion]]\" and the five-act poetic tragedy \"Otho The Great\".<ref>{{cite news
column8: title= John Keats – autumnal idealist or trenchant social commentator?

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester is situated on a bed of [[Cretaceous]] lower chalk with small areas of clay and loam soil, inset with combined clay and rich sources of [[fuller's earth]].{{Citation needed
As with the rest of the UK, Winchester experiences an [[oceanic climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Köppen]] ''Cfb''). The nearest Met Office station is in [[Martyr Worthy]], just outside the city.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Aside from the city centre, there are several suburbs and neighbourhoods within the city, including:

column3: Map of the wards of Winchester itself within the wider [[City of Winchester]] District]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: From 1835 to 1974, Winchester was governed as a [[municipal borough]] of Hampshire.<ref>{{cite web
column4: website=www.british-history.ac.uk}}</ref> Until 1902 the city's affairs were also administered partly by its parishes: St Lawrence, St Mary Kalendar, St Maurice, St Michael, St Peter Colebrook, St Swithin, St Thomas, St John, St Bartholomew Hyde, Milland, St Faith, and St Peter Cheesehill, and its extra-parochial areas: Cathedral Precincts, St Mary's College Precincts, St Cross Hospital Precinct, and Wolvesey.<ref>{{cite web
column7: website=www.visionofbritain.org.uk}}</ref> Historically, the south of the city had come under the \"[[Liberty]] of the Soke\", and was thereby self-governing to a large extent.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Winchester: The soke - British History Online
column13: website=www.visionofbritain.org.uk}}</ref> Since 1974 the city has been governed as part of the wider [[City of Winchester]] district of [[Hampshire]]. The district has 16 electoral wards, Five of these cover the area of the city itself: St Barnabas, St Paul, St Luke, St Bartholomew, and St Michael;<ref>{{Cite web
column19: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> they have three councillors each apart from St Luke, which is a two-member ward. For [[Hampshire County Council]] elections, the City of Winchester district is made up of 7 wards, with Winchester Westgate and Winchester Eastgate covering the city itself.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The current ward boundaries were adopted in [[2016 Winchester City Council election
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: 2016]], when all seats were up for election. Since then, [[Winchester City Council elections]] take place in three out of every four years, with one third of the councillors elected in each election. From the [[2006 Winchester Council election
column3: 2006 election]] until the [[2010 Winchester City Council election
column4: 2010 election]] the council was led by [[Conservative Party (UK)
column10: date=19 April 2008}}</ref> In 2010 it was briefly controlled by the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)
column11: Liberal Democrats]], before being controlled by the Conservatives again from 2011 until [[2019 Winchester City Council election
column12: 2019]], when the Liberal Democrats took control.

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Winchester]] is currently represented in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom
column3: House of Commons]] by [[Steve Brine]], of the Conservatives, who in the [[2010 United Kingdom general election
column4: 2010 General Election]] beat Martin Tod, the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)
column5: Liberal Democrat]] candidate, by 3048 votes (a margin of 5.4%).<ref name=\"election_2010\">{{cite news
column7: title=Tories sweep in but lose control of city council
column11: date=May 2010}}</ref> [[Mark Oaten]] had previously won the seat for the Liberal Democrats during the 1997 general election in which he defeated [[Gerry Malone]], a Health Minister in [[John Major]]'s [[Conservative party (UK)
column12: Conservative]] Government who had held the seat since 1992. Brine was re-elected in 2015 and in 2017. In 2019 he briefly sat as an independent before being re-elected as a conservative in the 2019 election.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: [[Winchester Cathedral]] was originally built in 1079 and remains the longest Gothic cathedral in Europe. It contains much fine architecture spanning the 11th to the 16th centuries and is the place of interment of numerous [[Bishop of Winchester
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Bishops of Winchester]] (such as [[William of Wykeham]]), [[Anglo-Saxons
column3: Anglo-Saxon]] monarchs (such as [[Egbert of Wessex]]) and later monarchs such as King [[Canute the Great
column8: title=The Royal Tombs of Great Britain
column11: year=2004}}</ref> It was once an important [[pilgrim]]age centre and housed the [[shrine]] of [[Swithun
column12: Saint Swithun]]. The ancient [[Pilgrims' Way]] to [[Canterbury]] begins at Winchester. The plan of the earlier [[Old Minster, Winchester
column13: Old Minster]] is laid out in the grass adjoining the cathedral. The [[New Minster, Winchester
column14: New Minster]] (the original burial place of [[Alfred the Great]] and [[Edward the Elder]]<ref name=\"RTGB\" />) once stood beside it. The cathedral has a girls choir and a boys choir, who sing regularly in the cathedral.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester Cathedral Close contains a number of historic buildings from the time when the cathedral was also a [[priory]]. Of particular note is the ''[[Deanery]]'', which dates back to the 13th century. It was originally the Prior's House, and was the birthplace of [[Arthur, Prince of Wales]] in 1486. Not far away is ''Cheyney Court'', a mid 15th-century [[timber framing
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: timber-framed]] house incorporating the Porter's Lodge for the Priory Gate. It was the Bishop's court house.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The earliest [[hammer-beam]]ed building still standing in England is situated in the Cathedral Close, next to the Dean's garden. It is known as the ''Pilgrims' Hall'', as it was part of the hostelry used to accommodate the many pilgrims to Saint Swithun's shrine. Left-overs from the lavish banquets of the Priors (the monastic predecessors of the later Deans) would be given to the pilgrims, who were welcome to spend the night in the hall. It is thought by Winchester City Council to have been built in 1308. Now part of [[The Pilgrims' School]], the hall is used by the school for assemblies in the morning, drama lessons, plays, orchestral practices, Cathedral Waynflete{{clarify
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: date=September 2019}} rehearsals, the school's Senior Commoners' Choir rehearsals etc.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Entrance for pedestrians to the North [[garth (architecture)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: garth]] of the cathedral is via the Norman arches of Saint Maurice's tower, in the High Street.<ref>Hampshire Churches, Margaret Green,Winton Pubs.Ltd.1967. Page 90.</ref>

Norman]] bishop's palace, dating from 1110, but standing on the site of an earlier Saxon structure. It was enhanced by [[Henry de Blois]] during [[the Anarchy]] of his brother King [[Stephen of England
column3: Stephen]]'s reign. He was besieged there for some days. In the 16th century, Queen [[Mary I of England
column4: Mary Tudor]] and King [[Philip II of Spain]] were guests just before their wedding in the Cathedral. The building is now a ruin (maintained by [[English Heritage]]), but the chapel was incorporated into the new palace built in the 1680s, only one wing of which survives.

column3: The \"Winchester Round Table\" in the Great Hall of [[Winchester Castle]]]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester is well known for the Great Hall of [[Winchester Castle
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: its castle]], which was built in the 12th century. The Great Hall was rebuilt sometime between 1222 and 1235, and still exists in this form. It is famous for ''[[King Arthur]]'s [[Round Table]]'', which has hung in the hall from at least 1463. The table actually dates from the 13th century, and as such is not contemporary to Arthur. Despite this it is still of considerable historical interest and attracts many tourists. The table was originally unpainted, but was painted for [[Henry VIII of England
column3: King Henry VIII]] in 1522. The names of the legendary [[Knights of the Round Table]] are written around the edge of the table surmounted by King Arthur on his throne. Opposite the table are [[Prince Charles]]'s 'Wedding Gates'. In the grounds of the Great Hall is a recreation of a [[Middle Ages
column4: medieval]] garden. Apart from the hall, only a few excavated remains of the stronghold survive among the modern Law Courts. The buildings were supplanted by the adjacent [[King's House, Winchester
column5: King's House]], now incorporated into the [[Peninsula Barracks]] where there are five military museums.<ref>{{cite web
column9: publisher=Winchester's Military Museums}}</ref> (The training that used to be carried out at the barracks is now done by the [[Army Training Regiment]] Winchester, based at the [[Sir John Moore Barracks]], {{convert
column13: sigfig=1}} outside the city).<ref name=\"Ministry of Defence training\">{{cite web

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Norman]] [[chapel]] of [[Hospital of St Cross]] were founded just outside the city centre by [[Henry de Blois]] in the 1130s. Since at least the 14th century, and still available today, a 'wayfarer's dole' of ale and bread has been handed out there. It was supposedly instigated to aid pilgrims on their way to [[Canterbury]].

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The City Museum, located on the corner of Great Minster Street and The Square, contains much information on the history of Winchester. Early examples of [[Winchester measure]]s of standard capacity are on display. The museum was one of the first purpose-built museums to be constructed outside London.<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> Local items featured include the Roman ''Venta Belgarum''<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Winchester City Museum  - Hampshire Cultural Trust
column9: website=https://www.hampshireculture.org.uk/winchester-city-museum}}</ref> gallery, and some genuine period shop interiors taken from the nearby High Street. Other places of cultural interest include the [[Westgate Museum]] (which showcases various items of [[weaponry]]), and the Historic Resources Centre, which holds many records related to the history of the city. In 2014 ownership of the City museum was transferred to the [[Hampshire Cultural Trust]] as part of a larger transfer of museums from [[Hampshire County Council]] and [[Winchester City Council]]<ref name=bbc14>{{cite news
column11: title=Hampshire and Winchester museums and art leased to trust

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: There are three 18-hole [[golf courses]]. Royal Winchester Golf Club is on downland adjacent to the [[Clarendon Way]] with fine views over distant country. Hockley Golf Club is dramatically positioned on [[St. Catherine's Hill, Hampshire

column3: High Court judge]]s for criminal and for civil cases (in the District Registry of the High Court). One of the most high-profile cases to be heard here was the [[Rose West]] murder trial in 1995.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester hosts one of the UK's larger [[farmers' market]]s, with about 100 stalls. It is certified by [[FARMA]].{{Citation needed
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: date=September 2015}} The market takes place on the second and last Sunday of the month in the city centre.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Four newspapers are published for Winchester. The weekly paid-for ''[[Hampshire Chronicle]]'', which started out in 1772 reporting national and international news, now concentrates on Winchester and the surrounding area. The ''Southern Daily Echo'' mostly concerns Southampton, but does also feature Winchester. It has an office shared with sister paper the Hampshire Chronicle. The ''Mid-Hants Observer'' is a free, weekly independent paper for Winchester and nearby villages. Its sister paper, the weekly ''Hampshire Independent'', which covers the whole county, is also based in Winchester. The free ''Winchester News Extra'' closed in 2017.
Winchester had its own radio station, [[Win 107.2
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Win FM]], from October 1999 to October 2007.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In October 2006, the [[Channel 4]] television programme ''The Best And Worst Places To Live In The UK'', the city was celebrated as the \"Best Place in the UK to Live in: 2006\".<ref name=\"WinchesterGreatest\" /> In the 2007 edition of the same programme, Winchester had slipped to second place, behind [[Edinburgh]].{{citation needed

A number of public figures and celebrities were students at [[Peter Symonds College]] in Winchester, including TV presenter and model [[Alexa Chung]], singer-songwriter and drummer [[Andy Burrows]], glamour model [[Lucy Pinder]], comedian [[Jack Dee]], Magician [[Ben Hart (magician)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Ben Hart]] and singer/actress [[Gina Beck]]. Harlequins rugby and England rugby player [[Joe Marchant (rugby union)
column3: Joe Marchant]]. Actor [[Colin Firth]] is from Winchester and was educated at Montgomery of Alamein School (now Kings' School). The adventurer and model [[Laura Bingham]] was born and brought up in the local area attending [[The Westgate School, Winchester
column4: The Westgate School]]. The singer-songwriter [[Frank Turner]] hails from Winchester, a fact that he often mentions at concerts as well as in his songs. The band [[Polly and the Billets Doux]] formed in Winchester, and are still based in the city. 2011 saw Winchester's first ever [[Oxjam]] Takeover music festival, held on 22 October.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In the medieval narrative poem, [[Sir Orfeo]], the main character Sir Orfeo is King of Winchester, which is said to be the modern name of [[Thrace]]. The final combat of the romance hero [[Guy of Warwick]] against the giant [[Colbrand (giant)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Colbrand]] takes place outside the walls of Winchester.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The [[Late Middle Ages]] author [[Sir Thomas Malory]] identified Winchester as the mythical home of [[Camelot]] and [[King Arthur]] in [[Le Morte d'Arthur]], his collection of medieval legends about the Arthurian myths.  (Malory's editor [[William Caxton]] disputed this, insisting that Camelot must be in [[Wales]]).
A scene in ''[[The History of Henry Esmond
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Henry Esmond]]'' (1852) by [[William Makepeace Thackeray]] is set in the choir of Winchester cathedral. Winchester is in part the model for ''Barchester'' in the ''[[Chronicles of Barsetshire
column3: Barsetshire]]'' novels of [[Anthony Trollope]], who attended Winchester College; ''[[The Warden]]'' (1855) is said to be based on a scandal at the [[Hospital of St Cross]]. A fictionalised Winchester appears as ''Wintoncester'' in [[Thomas Hardy
column4: Hardy]]'s ''[[Tess of the d'Urbervilles]]'' (1891). Some of the action in [[Sir Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s ''[[The Adventure of the Copper Beeches]]'' (1892) takes place in the city—the Black Swan hotel mentioned in the story formerly stood at the end of Southgate St and is still acknowledged by a figure on the outside of the building.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In [[Charles Kingsley]]'s romantic history ''[[Hereward the Wake (novel)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Hereward the Wake]]'' (1866), Hereward smashes his ash lance against the doors of the [[Westgate, Winchester]] showing by the strength of his arm that it is he. William the Conqueror is so impressed that he pardons him.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: A fictitious estate near Winchester is the scene of a crime in the [[Sherlock Holmes]] adventure, ''[[The Problem of Thor Bridge]]'' (1922).

column5: ''An Excellent Mystery'']], part of the [[Brother Cadfael]] chronicles by [[Edith Pargeter]] writing as Ellis Peters. In [[Philip Pullman]]'s novel ''[[The Subtle Knife]]'' (part of the ''[[His Dark Materials]]'' trilogy) the main male protagonist, Will Parry, comes from Winchester. 1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Merlin]]'', King Uther's first conquest of Britain begins with Winchester, which Merlin foresaw would fall.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In the novel ''[[The Pillars of the Earth]]'', by [[Ken Follett]], which traces English historical events from 1123 C.E. to 1174 C.E., Winchester and its cathedral figure prominently in several chapters. The fictional town of Kingsbridge in the novel is based on Winchester, as Follett explained in the first episode of his [[Channel 4]] 2013 documentary series ''Ken Follett's Journey into the Dark Ages''.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Ken Follett's Journey into the Dark Ages
column6: accessdate=1 March 2013}}</ref> Accounts of wool merchants and their trading with sheep farmers in Winchester are related to the reader. The reign of Stephen is described and his military actions are recounted, including first-person \"reporting\" of the Battle of Lincoln on 2 February 1141.

Winchester's major landmark is [[Winchester Cathedral]], one of the largest cathedrals in Europe, with the distinction of having the longest nave and overall length of all [[Gothic architecture
column3: Gothic]] cathedrals in Europe. The city is home to the [[University of Winchester]] and [[Winchester College]], the oldest public school in the United Kingdom still using its original buildings.{{citation needed

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The area around Winchester has been inhabited since [[Prehistoric Britain
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: prehistoric times]], with three [[British Iron Age
column5: St. Catherine's Hill]], and Worthy Down all nearby. In the [[Late Iron Age]], a more urban settlement type developed, known as an ''[[oppidum]]'', although the archaeology of this phase remains obscure. It was overrun by the confederation of [[Gauls
column7: tribes]] known as the [[Belgae]] sometime in the 1st century BCE. It seems to have been known as '''Wentā''' or '''Venta''', derived from the [[Common Brittonic
column8: Brittonic]] for \"town\" or \"meeting place\",<ref>Matasović, Ranko. [http://iedo.brillonline.nl/dictionaries/lemma.html?id=17429 \"wentā\" in the ''Etymological Dictionary of Proto-Celtic'' at ''Indo-European Etymological Dictionaries Online''. Brill Online, 2014. Accessed 24 July 2014.]{{dead link
column11: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> or the word for \"white\" ([[Welsh language
column12: Welsh]] ''gwyn''), due to Winchester's situation upon chalk.<ref>{{cite book
column15: title=Observations Upon Certain Roman Roads and Towns in the South of Britain

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: After the [[Roman conquest of Britain]], the settlement served as the capital ({{lang-la
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: civitas}}) of the Belgae and was distinguished as '''Venta Belgarum''', \"Venta of the Belgae\". Although in the early years of the Roman province it was of subsidiary importance to [[Silchester Roman Town
column4: Chichester]], Venta eclipsed them both by the latter half of the second century.<ref>Cunliffe B. ''Wessex to AD 1000'' 1997</ref> At the beginning of the third century, Winchester was given protective stone walls.<ref>{{cite web
column9: accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref> At around this time the city covered an area of {{convert
column11: acres}}, making it among the largest towns in Roman Britain by surface area.<ref name=\"Roman towns\">{{cite web
column15: accessdate=18 June 2014}}</ref> There was a limited suburban area outside the walls.<ref>{{cite web
column18: accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref> Like many other Roman towns however, Winchester began to decline in the later fourth century.<ref name=\"Roman towns\"/><ref>{{cite web

column3: Statue of [[Alfred the Great]] by [[Hamo Thornycroft]] in Winchester]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: After the [[Roman withdrawal from Britain]] in 410, urban life seems to have continued at Venta Belgarum until around 450, and a small administrative centre might have continued after that on the site of the later Anglo-Saxon palace. [[David Nash Ford
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Ford]] identifies the community as the {{nowrap
column12: Fort]] Venta\") is listed by [[Nennius]] among the 28 cities of [[Sub-Roman Britain
column14: History of the Britons]]''.<ref name=nashford>Ford, David Nash. \"[http://www.britannia.com/history/ebk/articles/nenniuscities.html The 28 Cities of Britain] {{Webarchive
column16: date=15 April 2016 }}\" at Britannia. 2000.</ref> Amid the [[Saxon invasions of Britain]], cemeteries dating to the 6th and 7th centuries suggest a revival of settlement.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: [[File:Anglo-Saxon Chronicle - Wintan ceastre (British Library Cotton MS Tiberius A VI, folio 12r).jpg
column4: A mention of Wintan-ceastre in the ''Anglo-Saxon Chronicle'']]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The city became known as '''Wintan-ceastre''' (\"Fort Venta\") in [[Old English]].<ref name=\"Anglo-Saxon Dictionary\">{{cite web
column6: accessdate=18 June 2014}}</ref> In 648, [[King Cenwalh of Wessex
column8: Wessex]] erected the Church of SS Peter and Paul, later known as the [[Old Minster, Winchester
column9: Old Minster]]. This became a cathedral in the 660s when the West Saxon bishopric was transferred from [[Dorchester-on-Thames]]. The present form of the city dates from reconstruction in the late 9th century, when [[Alfred the Great
column10: King Alfred the Great]] obliterated the Roman street plan in favour of a new grid in order to provide better defence against the [[Viking invasions of Britain
column11: Vikings]]. The city's first mint appears to date from this period.<ref name=WB>{{cite encyclopedia
column12: encyclopedia=The Wiley Blackwell Encyclopaedia of Anglo-Saxon England

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In the early 10th century there were two new ecclesiastical establishments: the convent of [[Nunnaminster]], founded by Alfred's widow [[Ealhswith]],<ref>*{{cite encyclopedia
column6: encyclopedia= Oxford Dictionary of National Biography
column12: New Minster]]. Bishop [[Æthelwold of Winchester]] was a leading figure in the monastic reform movement of the later 10th century. He expelled the secular canons of both minsters and replaced them with monks. He created the drainage system, the \"Lockburn\", which served as the town drain until 1875, and still survives. Also in the late 10th century, the Old Minster was enlarged as a centre of the cult of the 9th century [[Bishop of Winchester]], Saint [[Swithun]]. The three minsters were the home of what architectural historian John Crook describes as \"the supreme artistic achievements\" of the ''Winchester School''.<ref name=WB/>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The consensus among historians of Anglo-Saxon England is that the court was mobile in this period and there was no fixed capital.<ref>{{cite book
column14: title=Æthelstan: the first king of England
column22: title=Citadel of the Saxons: The Rise of Early London
column27: isbn=978-1-3501-3568-0}}</ref> [[Martin Biddle]] has suggested that Winchester was a centre for royal administration in the 7th and 8th centuries, but this is questioned by [[Barbara Yorke]], who sees it as significant that the shire was named after Hamtun, the forerunner of [[Southampton]].<ref>{{cite journal
column31: journal=Proceedings of the Hampshire Field Club and Archaeological Society
column32: title=The Foundation of the Old Minster and the Status of Winchester in the Seventh and Eighth Centuries
column36: issn= 0142-8950}}</ref> However, Winchester is described by the historian Catherine Cubitt as \"the premier city of the West Saxon kingdom\"<ref>{{cite book
column41: title=A Companion to the Early Middle Ages: Britain and Ireland c.500- c.1100
column47: isbn=978-1-118-42513-8}}</ref> and [[Janet Nelson]] describes London and Winchester as Alfred the Great's \"proto-capitals\".<ref>{{cite book
column50: chapter=Power and authority at the Court of Alfred
column55: title= Essays on Anglo-Saxon and Related Themes in Memory of Lynne Grundy
column59: publisher=King's College London Centre for Late Antique & Medieval Studies

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: There was a fire in the city in 1141 during the [[Rout of Winchester]]. Much later, [[William of Wykeham]] played a role in the city's restoration. As [[Bishop of Winchester]] he was responsible for much of the current structure of the cathedral, and he founded the still extant public school [[Winchester College]]. During the [[Middle Ages]], the city was an important centre of the wool trade, before going into a slow decline.{{Citation needed
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: date=August 2016}} The [[curfew bell]] in the bell tower (near the clock in the picture), still sounds at 8:00 pm each evening.

column3: Winchester High Street in the mid 19th century.]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Jews lived in Winchester from at least 1148, and in the 13th century the Jewish community in the city was one of the most important in England. There was an [[Archa (document store)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: archa]] in the city, and the Jewish quarter was located in the city's heart (present day Jewry street). There were a series of [[blood libel]] claims against the Jewish community in the 1220s and 1230s, which likely was the cause of the hanging of the community's leader, Abraham Pinch, in front of the synagogue of which he was the head. [[Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester
column3: Simon de Montfort]] ransacked the Jewish quarter in 1264, and in 1290 all Jews were [[Edict of Expulsion
column7: publisher=The Museum of the Jewish People at Beit Hatfutsot

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The City Cross (also known as the [[Buttercross]]) has been dated to the 15th century, and features 12 statues of the [[Virgin Mary]], other saints and various historical figures. Several statues appear to have been added throughout the structure's history. In 1770, [[Thomas Dummer]] purchased the Buttercross from the Corporation of Winchester, intending to have it re-erected at [[Cranbury Park]], near [[Otterbourne]]. When his workmen arrived to dismantle the cross, they were prevented from doing so by the people of the city, who \"organised a small riot\",<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate= 23 September 2009}}</ref> and they were forced to abandon their task. The agreement with the city was cancelled and Dummer erected a [[lath and plaster]] facsimile, which stood in the park for about sixty years before it was destroyed by the weather.<ref name = \"Yonge8\">{{cite web
column15: authorlink = Charlotte M. Yonge}}</ref> The Buttercross itself was restored by [[George Gilbert Scott]] in 1865, and still stands in the High Street. It is now a [[Scheduled Ancient Monument]].<ref>{{cite web
column16: title= City Cross or 'Butter Cross', Winchester

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Three notable bronze sculptures can be seen in or from the High Street by major sculptors of the 19th and 20th centuries, the earliest a monumental statue of [[Queen Victoria]], now in the [[Great Hall]], by [[Sir Alfred Gilbert]] (also known as the sculptor of '[[Eros]]' in London's Piccadilly Circus), [[King Alfred]], facing the city with raised sword from the centre of The Broadway, by [[Hamo Thornycroft]] and the modern striking ''[[Horse and Rider (Frink)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Horse and Rider]]'' by [[Dame Elizabeth Frink]] at the entrance to the Law Courts.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The novelist [[Jane Austen]] died in Winchester on 18 July 1817 and is buried in the cathedral.<ref>{{cite news
column6: date=14 November 2011}}</ref> While staying in Winchester from mid-August to October 1819, the Romantic poet [[John Keats]] wrote \"Isabella\", \"St. Agnes' Eve\", \"[[To Autumn]]\", \"Lamia\" and parts of \"[[Hyperion (poem)
column7: Hyperion]]\" and the five-act poetic tragedy \"Otho The Great\".<ref>{{cite news
column8: title= John Keats – autumnal idealist or trenchant social commentator?

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 2013, businesses involved in the housing market were reported by a local newspaper as saying that the city's architectural and historical interest, and its fast links to other towns and cities, had led Winchester to become one of the most expensive and desirable areas of the country and {{Fix
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: text=who?}}ranked Winchester as one of the least deprived areas in England and Wales.<ref name=WinchesterGreatest>{{cite news
column3: title=Winchester hits top ten list of places to live in the UK

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester is situated on a bed of [[Cretaceous]] lower chalk with small areas of clay and loam soil, inset with combined clay and rich sources of [[fuller's earth]].{{Citation needed
As with the rest of the UK, Winchester experiences an [[oceanic climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Köppen]] ''Cfb''). The nearest Met Office station is in [[Martyr Worthy]], just outside the city.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Aside from the city centre, there are several suburbs and neighbourhoods within the city, including:

column3: Map of the wards of Winchester itself within the wider [[City of Winchester]] District]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: From 1835 to 1974, Winchester was governed as a [[municipal borough]] of Hampshire.<ref>{{cite web
column4: website=www.british-history.ac.uk}}</ref> Until 1902 the city's affairs were also administered partly by its parishes: St Lawrence, St Mary Kalendar, St Maurice, St Michael, St Peter Colebrook, St Swithin, St Thomas, St John, St Bartholomew Hyde, Milland, St Faith, and St Peter Cheesehill, and its extra-parochial areas: Cathedral Precincts, St Mary's College Precincts, St Cross Hospital Precinct, and Wolvesey.<ref>{{cite web
column7: website=www.visionofbritain.org.uk}}</ref> Historically, the south of the city had come under the \"[[Liberty]] of the Soke\", and was thereby self-governing to a large extent.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Winchester: The soke - British History Online
column13: website=www.visionofbritain.org.uk}}</ref> Since 1974 the city has been governed as part of the wider [[City of Winchester]] district of [[Hampshire]]. The district has 16 electoral wards, Five of these cover the area of the city itself: St Barnabas, St Paul, St Luke, St Bartholomew, and St Michael;<ref>{{Cite web
column19: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> they have three councillors each apart from St Luke, which is a two-member ward. For [[Hampshire County Council]] elections, the City of Winchester district is made up of 7 wards, with Winchester Westgate and Winchester Eastgate covering the city itself.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The current ward boundaries were adopted in [[2016 Winchester City Council election
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: 2016]], when all seats were up for election. Since then, [[Winchester City Council elections]] take place in three out of every four years, with one third of the councillors elected in each election. From the [[2006 Winchester Council election
column3: 2006 election]] until the [[2010 Winchester City Council election
column4: 2010 election]] the council was led by [[Conservative Party (UK)
column10: date=19 April 2008}}</ref> In 2010 it was briefly controlled by the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)
column11: Liberal Democrats]], before being controlled by the Conservatives again from 2011 until [[2019 Winchester City Council election
column12: 2019]], when the Liberal Democrats took control.

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Winchester]] is currently represented in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom
column3: House of Commons]] by [[Steve Brine]], of the Conservatives, who in the [[2010 United Kingdom general election
column4: 2010 General Election]] beat Martin Tod, the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)
column5: Liberal Democrat]] candidate, by 3048 votes (a margin of 5.4%).<ref name=\"election_2010\">{{cite news
column7: title=Tories sweep in but lose control of city council
column11: date=May 2010}}</ref> [[Mark Oaten]] had previously won the seat for the Liberal Democrats during the 1997 general election in which he defeated [[Gerry Malone]], a Health Minister in [[John Major]]'s [[Conservative party (UK)
column12: Conservative]] Government who had held the seat since 1992. Brine was re-elected in 2015 and in 2017. In 2019 he briefly sat as an independent before being re-elected as a conservative in the 2019 election.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: [[Winchester Cathedral]] was originally built in 1079 and remains the longest Gothic cathedral in Europe. It contains much fine architecture spanning the 11th to the 16th centuries and is the place of interment of numerous [[Bishop of Winchester
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Bishops of Winchester]] (such as [[William of Wykeham]]), [[Anglo-Saxons
column3: Anglo-Saxon]] monarchs (such as [[Egbert of Wessex]]) and later monarchs such as King [[Canute the Great
column8: title=The Royal Tombs of Great Britain
column11: year=2004}}</ref> It was once an important [[pilgrim]]age centre and housed the [[shrine]] of [[Swithun
column12: Saint Swithun]]. The ancient [[Pilgrims' Way]] to [[Canterbury]] begins at Winchester. The plan of the earlier [[Old Minster, Winchester
column13: Old Minster]] is laid out in the grass adjoining the cathedral. The [[New Minster, Winchester
column14: New Minster]] (the original burial place of [[Alfred the Great]] and [[Edward the Elder]]<ref name=\"RTGB\" />) once stood beside it. The cathedral has a girls choir and a boys choir, who sing regularly in the cathedral.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester Cathedral Close contains a number of historic buildings from the time when the cathedral was also a [[priory]]. Of particular note is the ''[[Deanery]]'', which dates back to the 13th century. It was originally the Prior's House, and was the birthplace of [[Arthur, Prince of Wales]] in 1486. Not far away is ''Cheyney Court'', a mid 15th-century [[timber framing
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: timber-framed]] house incorporating the Porter's Lodge for the Priory Gate. It was the Bishop's court house.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The earliest [[hammer-beam]]ed building still standing in England is situated in the Cathedral Close, next to the Dean's garden. It is known as the ''Pilgrims' Hall'', as it was part of the hostelry used to accommodate the many pilgrims to Saint Swithun's shrine. Left-overs from the lavish banquets of the Priors (the monastic predecessors of the later Deans) would be given to the pilgrims, who were welcome to spend the night in the hall. It is thought by Winchester City Council to have been built in 1308. Now part of [[The Pilgrims' School]], the hall is used by the school for assemblies in the morning, drama lessons, plays, orchestral practices, Cathedral Waynflete{{clarify
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: date=September 2019}} rehearsals, the school's Senior Commoners' Choir rehearsals etc.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Entrance for pedestrians to the North [[garth (architecture)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: garth]] of the cathedral is via the Norman arches of Saint Maurice's tower, in the High Street.<ref>Hampshire Churches, Margaret Green,Winton Pubs.Ltd.1967. Page 90.</ref>

Norman]] bishop's palace, dating from 1110, but standing on the site of an earlier Saxon structure. It was enhanced by [[Henry de Blois]] during [[the Anarchy]] of his brother King [[Stephen of England
column3: Stephen]]'s reign. He was besieged there for some days. In the 16th century, Queen [[Mary I of England
column4: Mary Tudor]] and King [[Philip II of Spain]] were guests just before their wedding in the Cathedral. The building is now a ruin (maintained by [[English Heritage]]), but the chapel was incorporated into the new palace built in the 1680s, only one wing of which survives.

column3: The \"Winchester Round Table\" in the Great Hall of [[Winchester Castle]]]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester is well known for the Great Hall of [[Winchester Castle
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: its castle]], which was built in the 12th century. The Great Hall was rebuilt sometime between 1222 and 1235, and still exists in this form. It is famous for ''[[King Arthur]]'s [[Round Table]]'', which has hung in the hall from at least 1463. The table actually dates from the 13th century, and as such is not contemporary to Arthur. Despite this it is still of considerable historical interest and attracts many tourists. The table was originally unpainted, but was painted for [[Henry VIII of England
column3: King Henry VIII]] in 1522. The names of the legendary [[Knights of the Round Table]] are written around the edge of the table surmounted by King Arthur on his throne. Opposite the table are [[Prince Charles]]'s 'Wedding Gates'. In the grounds of the Great Hall is a recreation of a [[Middle Ages
column4: medieval]] garden. Apart from the hall, only a few excavated remains of the stronghold survive among the modern Law Courts. The buildings were supplanted by the adjacent [[King's House, Winchester
column5: King's House]], now incorporated into the [[Peninsula Barracks]] where there are five military museums.<ref>{{cite web
column9: publisher=Winchester's Military Museums}}</ref> (The training that used to be carried out at the barracks is now done by the [[Army Training Regiment]] Winchester, based at the [[Sir John Moore Barracks]], {{convert
column13: sigfig=1}} outside the city).<ref name=\"Ministry of Defence training\">{{cite web

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Norman]] [[chapel]] of [[Hospital of St Cross]] were founded just outside the city centre by [[Henry de Blois]] in the 1130s. Since at least the 14th century, and still available today, a 'wayfarer's dole' of ale and bread has been handed out there. It was supposedly instigated to aid pilgrims on their way to [[Canterbury]].

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The City Museum, located on the corner of Great Minster Street and The Square, contains much information on the history of Winchester. Early examples of [[Winchester measure]]s of standard capacity are on display. The museum was one of the first purpose-built museums to be constructed outside London.<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> Local items featured include the Roman ''Venta Belgarum''<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Winchester City Museum  - Hampshire Cultural Trust
column9: website=https://www.hampshireculture.org.uk/winchester-city-museum}}</ref> gallery, and some genuine period shop interiors taken from the nearby High Street. Other places of cultural interest include the [[Westgate Museum]] (which showcases various items of [[weaponry]]), and the Historic Resources Centre, which holds many records related to the history of the city. In 2014 ownership of the City museum was transferred to the [[Hampshire Cultural Trust]] as part of a larger transfer of museums from [[Hampshire County Council]] and [[Winchester City Council]]<ref name=bbc14>{{cite news
column11: title=Hampshire and Winchester museums and art leased to trust

column7: water mills]] driven by the [[River Itchen, Hampshire
column8: River Itchen]] that runs through the city centre. The mill has recently been restored, and is again milling corn by water power. It is owned by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty

Next to it is Milner Hall, built in the 1780s it was the first Catholic church to be [[consecrated]] since 1558.<ref>[http://taking-stock.org.uk/Home/Dioceses/Diocese-of-Portsmouth/Winchester-The-Milner-Hall-St-Peter Winchester (The Milner Hall) - St Peter] {{Webarchive

The West Downs campus is a short walk away, and houses student facilities and accommodation and the business school.<ref>{{cite news

Winchester has a [[rugby union]] team, [[Winchester RFC]], and an [[Athletics (sport)

Hockley Golf Club is dramatically positioned on [[St. Catherine's Hill, Hampshire

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: South Western Railway]] trains from [[London Waterloo railway station
column6: Southampton]], as well as by [[CrossCountry]] between [[Bournemouth railway station
column7: Bournemouth]], and either [[Manchester Piccadilly railway station
column9: Newcastle]] via [[Birmingham New Street railway station
column10: Birmingham]]. Historically it was also served by a line to London via [[Alton railway station
column11: Alton]], which partially survives as the [[Watercress Line]]. The closure of this line removed an alternative route between London and Winchester when, due to engineering works or other reasons, the main line was temporarily unusable.  There was a second station called [[Winchester (Chesil) railway station
column12: Winchester Chesil]] served by the [[Didcot, Newbury and Southampton Railway]], this closed in the 1960s.<ref name=\"Hampshire County Council\">{{cite news
column15: year=2011}}</ref>  This line provided a link to the [[The Midlands
column16: Midlands]] and the [[North]], bypassing the present longer route through [[Reading, Berkshire

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester Combined Court Centre consists of a [[crown court]] and [[county court]]. It is administered by [[Her Majesty's Courts Service]], an [[Executive Agency]] of the [[Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Ministry of Justice]]. Winchester is a first-tier court centre and is visited by [[High Court judge (England and Wales)
column3: High Court judge]]s for criminal and for civil cases (in the District Registry of the High Court). One of the most high-profile cases to be heard here was the [[Rose West]] murder trial in 1995.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester has a separate district [[probate]] registry, which is part of the [[High Court of Justice
column10: df=dmy-all }}</ref> This Court is separate from the main court establishment at the top of Winchester High Street and deals only with probate matters.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: There is a heavily populated Victorian prison, [[HM Prison Winchester
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: HMP Winchester]], opposite the hospital, on the B3040 heading up west from the town centre.<ref>{{cite news

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Since 1974 Winchester has hosted the annual [[Winchester Hat Fair
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Hat Fair]], a celebration of [[street theatre]] that includes performances, workshops, and gatherings at several venues around the city.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester is the home of the award-winning [[Blue Apple Theatre]], a company of actors.<ref name=\"QVA Announcement\">{{cite web
column3: title=Blue Apple Theatre Honored with Queen's Award for Voluntary Service 2012
column6: accessdate=26 October 2012}}</ref><ref name=\"Hampshire Chronicle Article\">{{cite web
column8: title=Blue Apple Theatre to take Hamlet on the road (From Hampshire Chronicle)

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester hosts one of the UK's larger [[farmers' market]]s, with about 100 stalls. It is certified by [[FARMA]].{{Citation needed
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: date=September 2015}} The market takes place on the second and last Sunday of the month in the city centre.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Four newspapers are published for Winchester. The weekly paid-for ''[[Hampshire Chronicle]]'', which started out in 1772 reporting national and international news, now concentrates on Winchester and the surrounding area. The ''Southern Daily Echo'' mostly concerns Southampton, but does also feature Winchester. It has an office shared with sister paper the Hampshire Chronicle. The ''Mid-Hants Observer'' is a free, weekly independent paper for Winchester and nearby villages. Its sister paper, the weekly ''Hampshire Independent'', which covers the whole county, is also based in Winchester. The free ''Winchester News Extra'' closed in 2017.
Winchester had its own radio station, [[Win 107.2
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Win FM]], from October 1999 to October 2007.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In October 2006, the [[Channel 4]] television programme ''The Best And Worst Places To Live In The UK'', the city was celebrated as the \"Best Place in the UK to Live in: 2006\".<ref name=\"WinchesterGreatest\" /> In the 2007 edition of the same programme, Winchester had slipped to second place, behind [[Edinburgh]].{{citation needed

A number of public figures and celebrities were students at [[Peter Symonds College]] in Winchester, including TV presenter and model [[Alexa Chung]], singer-songwriter and drummer [[Andy Burrows]], glamour model [[Lucy Pinder]], comedian [[Jack Dee]], Magician [[Ben Hart (magician)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Ben Hart]] and singer/actress [[Gina Beck]]. Harlequins rugby and England rugby player [[Joe Marchant (rugby union)
column3: Joe Marchant]]. Actor [[Colin Firth]] is from Winchester and was educated at Montgomery of Alamein School (now Kings' School). The adventurer and model [[Laura Bingham]] was born and brought up in the local area attending [[The Westgate School, Winchester
column4: The Westgate School]]. The singer-songwriter [[Frank Turner]] hails from Winchester, a fact that he often mentions at concerts as well as in his songs. The band [[Polly and the Billets Doux]] formed in Winchester, and are still based in the city. 2011 saw Winchester's first ever [[Oxjam]] Takeover music festival, held on 22 October.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In March 2016, Winchester was named as the best place to live in Britain by the \"Sunday Times Best Places To Live\" guide.<ref>{{cite web
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: title=Winchester named best place to live in Britain

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In the medieval narrative poem, [[Sir Orfeo]], the main character Sir Orfeo is King of Winchester, which is said to be the modern name of [[Thrace]]. The final combat of the romance hero [[Guy of Warwick]] against the giant [[Colbrand (giant)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Colbrand]] takes place outside the walls of Winchester.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The [[Late Middle Ages]] author [[Sir Thomas Malory]] identified Winchester as the mythical home of [[Camelot]] and [[King Arthur]] in [[Le Morte d'Arthur]], his collection of medieval legends about the Arthurian myths.  (Malory's editor [[William Caxton]] disputed this, insisting that Camelot must be in [[Wales]]).
A scene in ''[[The History of Henry Esmond
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Henry Esmond]]'' (1852) by [[William Makepeace Thackeray]] is set in the choir of Winchester cathedral. Winchester is in part the model for ''Barchester'' in the ''[[Chronicles of Barsetshire
column3: Barsetshire]]'' novels of [[Anthony Trollope]], who attended Winchester College; ''[[The Warden]]'' (1855) is said to be based on a scandal at the [[Hospital of St Cross]]. A fictionalised Winchester appears as ''Wintoncester'' in [[Thomas Hardy
column4: Hardy]]'s ''[[Tess of the d'Urbervilles]]'' (1891). Some of the action in [[Sir Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s ''[[The Adventure of the Copper Beeches]]'' (1892) takes place in the city—the Black Swan hotel mentioned in the story formerly stood at the end of Southgate St and is still acknowledged by a figure on the outside of the building.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In [[Charles Kingsley]]'s romantic history ''[[Hereward the Wake (novel)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Hereward the Wake]]'' (1866), Hereward smashes his ash lance against the doors of the [[Westgate, Winchester]] showing by the strength of his arm that it is he. William the Conqueror is so impressed that he pardons him.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: A fictitious estate near Winchester is the scene of a crime in the [[Sherlock Holmes]] adventure, ''[[The Problem of Thor Bridge]]'' (1922).

In [[Gerry Anderson]]'s 1967 and 1968 programme ''[[Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons]]'', background material published by, or with the approval of, Anderson identifies Winchester as the birthplace of the main character, [[Captain Scarlet (character)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Captain Scarlet]], real name Paul Metcalfe.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester is the main location of [[Samuel Youd
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: John Christopher]]'s post-apocalyptic science fiction series, ''[[Sword of the Spirits]]''. Winchester Cathedral is featured in James Herbert's horror novel ''[[The Fog (1975 novel)
column3: The Fog]]''. The Siege of Winchester in 1141, part of [[The Anarchy]] (a civil war) between [[Stephen of England
column4: King Stephen]] and the [[Empress Matilda]], is an important plot element in the detective novel [[An Excellent Mystery (novel)
column5: ''An Excellent Mystery'']], part of the [[Brother Cadfael]] chronicles by [[Edith Pargeter]] writing as Ellis Peters. In [[Philip Pullman]]'s novel ''[[The Subtle Knife]]'' (part of the ''[[His Dark Materials]]'' trilogy) the main male protagonist, Will Parry, comes from Winchester. However, little of the book is set there.

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Merlin]]'', King Uther's first conquest of Britain begins with Winchester, which Merlin foresaw would fall.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In the novel ''[[The Pillars of the Earth]]'', by [[Ken Follett]], which traces English historical events from 1123 C.E. to 1174 C.E., Winchester and its cathedral figure prominently in several chapters. The fictional town of Kingsbridge in the novel is based on Winchester, as Follett explained in the first episode of his [[Channel 4]] 2013 documentary series ''Ken Follett's Journey into the Dark Ages''.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Ken Follett's Journey into the Dark Ages
column6: accessdate=1 March 2013}}</ref> Accounts of wool merchants and their trading with sheep farmers in Winchester are related to the reader. The reign of Stephen is described and his military actions are recounted, including first-person \"reporting\" of the Battle of Lincoln on 2 February 1141.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In the Japanese manga ''[[Death Note]]'', The Wammy's House, an orphanage founded by Quillish Wammy, where the detective L's successors (Mello, Near, and Matt) are raised, is located in Winchester.

column3: David Nicholls]], the male protagonist Dexter Mayhew went to the public school [[Winchester College]].<ref name=\"One Day\">{{cite web
column12: df=dmy-all}}</ref> This is frequently referred to throughout the book, as well as mentioning St. Swithin's Day and the St. Swithin's weather myth.<ref name=\"One Day\"/><ref name=\"David Dicholls\">{{cite news
column13: title=David Nicholls, the man who made a nation cry

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: [[Patrick Gale]]'s 2009 book ''The Whole Day Through'' is set in Winchester. In [[S. M. Stirling]]'s 2007 novel, ''[[The Sunrise Lands]]'', it is revealed that the British capital has been moved to Winchester. Winchester is an important setting in [[The Saxon Stories]] by [[Bernard Cornwell]].

[[Frank Turner]] (singer-songwriter) who was raised in the nearby village of Meonstoke (part of the City of Winchester district), wrote and performs the song \"Wessex Boy\" describing Winchester, and how it remains his home. He names the Cathedral, the Buttercross and Jewry Street in his homage to the city.

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: List of twin towns and sister cities in the United Kingdom}}

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Winchester is [[Twin towns and sister cities

column8: title=British towns twinned with French towns

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: GER}} [[Gießen]], [[Hesse]], Germany<ref name=\"Hampshire\"/><ref name=\"Giessen twinnings\">{{cite web

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: [[Winchester, Virginia]], is named after the English city, whose Mayor has a standing invitation to be a part of the American city's [[Shenandoah Apple Blossom Festival]]. Winchester also gave its name (Frenchified to ''Bicêtre'') to a suburb of [[Paris]], from a manor built there by [[John of Pontoise]], [[Bishop of Winchester]], at the end of the 13th century. It is now the commune of [[Le Kremlin-Bicêtre]].
*[https://web.archive.org/web/20180103185658/http://www.geograph.org.uk/search.php?i=3349740 www.geograph.co.uk: photos of Winchester and surrounding area]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The '''Canada lynx''' (''Lynx canadensis'') is a medium-sized [[lynx]] native to [[North America]]. It ranges across [[Canada]] and [[Alaska]] extending into the United States portion of the [[Rocky Mountains]]. It is characterized by its long, dense fur, triangular ears with black tufts at the tips, and broad, [[snowshoe]]-like paws. Similar to the [[bobcat]] (''L. rufus''), the hindlimbs are remarkably longer than the forelimbs, so that the back appears to be sloping downward to the front. The lynx is a good swimmer and an agile climber. The Canada lynx stands {{convert
column7: abbr=on}} tall at the shoulder and weighs between {{convert
column13: abbr=on}}. This lynx was first [[scientific description
column15: Robert Kerr]] in 1792. Three [[subspecies]] are recognized.

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: nocturnal]] like its primary prey, the [[snowshoe hare]]. The strong dependence of this [[Specialist and generalist species
column3: specialist predator]] on snowshoe hares for food leads to an example of a prey-predator cycle. Canada lynxes respond to the cyclic rises and falls over the years in snowshoe hare populations in Alaska and central Canada—when hares are scarce lynxes tend to move to areas with more hares and tend to not produce litters, and as the numbers of the hare increase, so does the population of the lynx. The lynx waits for the hare in specific trails or \"ambush beds\", then pounces on it and kills it by a bite on its head, throat or the nape of its neck. Individuals of the same sex particularly tend to avoid each other, forming \"intrasexual\" territories. The mating season is roughly a month long (from March to early April). After a gestational period of two to three months, a litter of one to eight kittens is born. Offspring are weaned at 12 weeks.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: This lynx occurs predominantly in dense [[Taiga
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: boreal forest]]s, and its range heavily coincides with that of the snowshoe hare. Given its abundance throughout its range and no severe threats, this lynx has been listed as [[Least Concern]] on the [[IUCN Red List]]. This lynx is regularly trapped for the international fur trade in most of Alaska and Canada, but is protected in the southern half of its range due to threats such as habitat loss.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In his 1792 work ''The Animal Kingdom'', Scottish scientific writer [[Robert Kerr (writer)
column4: lynx]] from Canada, giving it the [[Binomial nomenclature
column16: taxonomy]] of the Canada lynx remained disputed through the 20th and early 21st centuries. In 1912, American zoologist [[Gerrit Miller]] placed the Canada lynx under the [[Genus (biology)
column17: genus]] ''Lynx'', with the name ''L. canadensis''.<ref>{{cite book
column21: title=List of North American land mammals in the United States National Museum, 1911
column26: date = 1912}}</ref> Until as late as the early 2000s, scientists were divided on whether ''Lynx'' should be considered a [[Subgenus (biology)
column28: subfamily]] itself; some even doubted if the Canada lynx should be considered a species on its own.<ref name=Tumlison>{{cite journal
column43: title=The Scientific Basis for Conserving Forest Carnivores: American Marten, Fisher, Lynx and Wolverine in the Western United States
column69: title=Wild Mammals of North America: Biology, Management, and Conservation
column79: W. C. Wozencraft]] revised the classification of [[Carnivora]] in 2005, and recognized the Canada lynx as a species under ''Lynx'', along with the [[bobcat]] (''L. rufus''), the [[Eurasian lynx]] (''L. lynx'') and the [[Iberian lynx]] (''L. pardinus''). In 2017, the Cat Classification Task Force of the [[IUCN]] Cat Specialist Group revised felid taxonomy, considering the Canada lynx a [[monotypic species]].<ref name=\"Catsg2017\">{{cite journal
column104: title=A revised taxonomy of the Felidae: The final report of the Cat Classification Task Force of the IUCN Cat Specialist Group
column108: url=https://repository.si.edu/bitstream/handle/10088/32616/A_revised_Felidae_Taxonomy_CatNews.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y}}</ref><!--this is not about taxonomy: <ref name=CanLynx>{{cite report
column113: title=Species assessment for Canada lynx (''Lynx canadensis'') in Wyoming
column114: publisher= [[United States Department of the Interior]], Bureau of Land Management
