→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: From 1970, Preston played keyboards (including piano, organ, clavinet and various synthesizers) for [[the Rolling Stones]], sometimes alongside pianists [[Nicky Hopkins]] and [[Ian Stewart (musician)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Ian Stewart]], on their albums ''[[Sticky Fingers]]'', ''[[Exile on Main St.]]'', ''[[Goats Head Soup]]'', ''[[It's Only Rock 'n Roll]]'' and ''[[Black and Blue]]''. As the band's primary touring keyboardist from 1973 to 1977, he also performed as a support act with his own band (including [[Mick Taylor]] on guitar) on their [[The Rolling Stones 1973 European Tour
column3: 1973 European tour]]. A [[Munich]] performance from this tour was documented on Preston's album ''[[Live European Tour 1973]]''. In 1974, along with [[Bruce Fisher]], one of his regular songwriting collaborators in the 1970s, he composed one of Joe Cocker's biggest hits, \"[[You Are So Beautiful]]\". On October 11, 1975, he was the first musical guest on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''{{'}}s series premiere episode.<ref name=nyt/> Preston's 1973 song \"Do You Love Me\" was the basis for the Rolling Stones' track \"Melody\", released on ''Black and Blue'' in 1976. Although two of his songs were included in the band's 1975 and 1976 live sets, the Stones and Preston parted company in 1977, mainly due to a disagreement over money. He continued to play on solo records by Stones members like [[Mick Jagger]]'s ''[[Wandering Spirit (album)
column4: Wandering Spirit]]'', and made appearances on the band's ''[[Tattoo You]]'' and ''[[Bridges to Babylon]]''.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: After seven years with A&M, he signed with [[Motown]]. In 1979, he duetted with [[Syreeta Wright]] on the ballad \"[[With You I'm Born Again]]\",<ref name=nyt/> which reached number 4 on the charts in the US. Preston's career lost momentum in the 1980s due to his [[cocaine]] and alcohol addictions. He left Motown in 1984 and focused on session work, contributing to works by artists such as [[Luther Vandross]] (his organ solos were included on Vandross' 1985 hit \"Til My Baby Comes Home\"), [[Whitney Houston]] and [[Patti LaBelle]], among others. He served as musical director for ''[[Nightlife (TV series)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Nightlife]]'', a late-night [[talk show]] hosted by [[David Brenner]] that lasted one season from 1986 to 1987.<ref name=\"Chase\">
title=He's On His Own In Late-night TV

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston toured with [[Eric Clapton]], recorded with Gary Walker, one of the vocalists in his Los Angeles-based band, and worked with a wide range of other artists. He also toured with [[Ringo Starr]], appearing on [[Ringo Starr and His All-Starr Band
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: his 1990 live album]]. He was invited to become a member of [[The Band]] in 1991, after the death of piano player [[Stan Szelest]]. He performed on tour with the group,<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Billy Preston Makes The Band Born Again
column13: access-date=2019-11-05}}</ref> but the sentencing from his cocaine and sexual assault charges in 1991 ended the collaboration.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 1997, Billy Preston recorded the album ''You and I'', in Italy, with Italian band [[Novecento (group)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Novecento]]. The album was produced by Vaughn De Spenza and Novecento members [[Nicolosi Productions
column8: accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> In 1998, Preston played organ during the choir numbers on the [[UPN]] comedy show ''[[Good News (TV series)
column9: Good News]]''. The same year he sang and played synthesizer in the film ''[[Blues Brothers 2000]]'', as part of [[the Louisiana Gator Boys]] supergroup.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: On November 29, 2001, while touring and fighting his own health problems, Preston received the news that George Harrison had died, having long suffered from [[Head and neck cancer
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: throat cancer]]. Preston, among many of Harrison's longtime friends, performed in the 2002 [[Concert for George]] at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London. Preston's performance of \"My Sweet Lord\" received critical acclaim. Additionally, he sang \"[[Isn't It a Pity]]\", provided backing vocals on most of the other songs, and played the [[Hammond organ]] for the show.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 2002, Preston appeared on the [[Johnny Cash]] album ''[[American IV: The Man Comes Around]]'', playing piano on \"[[Personal Jesus]]\" and \"[[Tear-Stained Letter]]\".

In 2004, Preston toured with [[the Funk Brothers]] and [[Steve Winwood]] in Europe, and then with Clapton in Europe and North America. After the Clapton tours, he went to France, where he was featured in one episode of the ''Legends Rock TV Show.''<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Guest Artist of the Legends Rock TV Show
column6: accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> His performance included a duet with [[Sam Moore]] on \"You Are So Beautiful\"; this was Preston's last filmed concert.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 2004, Preston performed as a [[List of jazz organists
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: jazz organist]] on Ray Charles' ''[[Genius Loves Company]]'', an album of duets, on the song \"[[Here We Go Again (Ray Charles song)
column3: Here We Go Again]]\" with Charles and [[Norah Jones]].

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In March 2005, he appeared on the ''[[American Idol]]'' [[American Idol (season 4)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: fourth season]] finale. Playing piano, he performed \"[[With You I'm Born Again]]\" with [[Vonzell Solomon]] (who finished the contest in third place). The same year, he recorded \"Go Where No One's Gone Before\", the main title song for the [[anime]] series ''[[L/R: Licensed by Royalty]]''.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston played [[clavinet]] on the song \"Warlocks\" for the [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]] album ''[[Stadium Arcadium]]'' (2006). Although very ill by this point, he jumped out of his bed after hearing a tape of the song given to him by the band, recorded his part, and went back to bed.<ref>{{cite magazine
column3: title=Red Hot Chili Peppers - Peppers Get Sick Preston Out Of Bed
column5: accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> Preston's final recorded contributions were the gospel-tinged organ on the [[Neil Diamond]] album ''[[12 Songs (Neil Diamond album)
column6: 12 Songs]]'' (2005), and his keyboard work on ''[[The Road to Escondido]]'' (2006) by Eric Clapton and [[J. J. Cale]].

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In late 2005, Preston made his last public performance, in Los Angeles, to publicize the re-release of the 1972  documentary film ''[[The Concert for Bangladesh (film)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: The Concert for Bangladesh]]''. He played a set of three Harrison songs – \"Give Me Love\", \"My Sweet Lord\" and \"Isn't It a Pity\" – with [[Dhani Harrison]] and Starr joining on guitar and drums, respectively, for the last song.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston lived in [[London]] for a time,<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=28 October 2017}}</ref> possibly around 1969–1971, but he moved back to the US sometime in the early 1970s.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Billy Preston was brought up in the African-American [[Gospel music
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: gospel]] tradition; he was a committed Christian throughout his life and he openly expressed his faith in works such as his 1970s hit \"[[That's the Way God Planned It (song)
column3: That's the Way God Planned It]]\". However, his personal beliefs were sometimes at odds with the attitudes and musical expressions of the secular world of rock & roll in which he often worked; while he was apparently willing to put his religious views aside when working on tracks like [[John Lennon]]'s openly atheistic song \"[[God (John Lennon song)
column4: God]]\". Preston was also deeply attached to his mother, for whom he wrote the song that became his best-known composition, \"[[You Are So Beautiful]]\".<ref name=\"bbc.co.uk\">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00wqb5d ''Billy Preston: That's The Way God Planned It''], BBC Radio 4,  December 21, 2010.</ref>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Although the details did not become fully known to the general public until after his death, Preston struggled throughout his life to cope with his [[homosexuality]], and the lasting effects of the traumatic sexual abuse he suffered as a boy. Although his [[sexual orientation]] became known to friends and associates in the music world (such as [[Keith Richards]]), Preston did not publicly come out as gay until just before he died. This was reportedly partly because he felt that it conflicted with his deeply held religious beliefs and his lifelong association with the church, so he remained \"[[Coming out
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: in the closet]]\" until shortly before his death. Keith Richards' autobiography, ''Life'',<ref>{{cite book
column10: quote=And he was gay at a time when nobody could be openly gay, which added difficulties to his life. Billy could be, most of time, a bundle of fun. but sometimes he would get on the rag. I had to stop him from beating up his boyfriend in an elevator once.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
column28: date=July 25, 2011}}</ref> mentions Billy Preston's struggles with his sexuality.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In an interview for a 2010 [[BBC Radio 4]] documentary on his life and career, Preston's manager Joyce Moore revealed that after she began handling his affairs, Preston opened up to her about the lifelong trauma he had suffered as the result of being sexually abused as a boy. Preston told Moore that at about the age of nine, after he and his mother moved to Los Angeles from Houston to perform in a touring production of ''[[Amos 'n' Andy]]'', he was repeatedly abused by the touring company's pianist. When Preston told his mother about the abuse, she did not believe him, and failed to protect him.<ref name=\"bbc.co.uk\" /> The abuse subsequently went on for the entire summer, and Preston stated that he was also later abused by a local pastor.

Another traumatic incident, which reportedly affected Preston deeply, occurred in the early 1970s, while he was engaged to actress/model Kathy Silva. At this time Preston had become close friends with musician [[Sly Stone]], and made many contributions to Stone's recordings of the period (including the landmark album ''[[There's a Riot Goin' On]]''). According to Moore, Preston was devastated when he came home one day to find Stone in bed with Silva (who later famously married Stone on stage at Madison Square Garden). According to Moore, Silva's affair with Stone was the trigger that led Preston to stop having relationships with women. It was after this incident that he began abusing [[cocaine]] and having sex with men, and Moore has stated that she saw his drug abuse as his way of coping with the internal conflicts he felt about his sexual urges.<ref name=\"bbc.co.uk\"/><ref>[http://www.houstonpress.com/music/the-bitter-battle-over-fifth-beatle-billy-prestons-estate-6779599 Nate Jackson, \"The Bitter Battle over 'Fifth Beatle' Billy Preston's Estate\", ''Houston Press'', March 11, 2015 (retrieved December 1, 2015)]</ref>
In 1991, Preston checked into a drug rehabilitation program to treat his addictions.<ref>{{Cite magazine
column5: title=Singer Billy Preston To Seek Drug Treatment

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: drunk driving]] conviction in August 1991,<ref name=\"Jet Sentenced\">{{Cite magazine
column6: title=Billy Preston Sentenced To 30 Days In Jail
column11: via=}}</ref> Preston was arrested for sexually assaulting a 16-year-old Mexican boy, after picking him up at a gathering point for day laborers.<ref>{{Cite news
column13: title=Singer Billy Preston Arrested in Sex Case
column18: access-date=}}</ref> The boy told authorities that Preston took him to his Malibu home, smoked cocaine, showed him [[Pornography
column19: pornographic]] pictures and tried to assault him before he escaped.<ref name=\"AP no contest\">{{Cite web
column21: title=Musician Billy Preston Pleads No Contest to Assault and Drug Charges
column28: archive-date=}}</ref> Preston was also charged with [[Assault
column29: assault with a deadly weapon]] involving a man he picked up to do work at his home, the day before his arrest in the case involving the boy.<ref name=\"AP no contest\" /> After submitting to a drug test, Preston tested positive for cocaine. He entered [[nolo contendre
column30: no-contest pleas]] to the cocaine and assault charges. The sex charges which included misdemeanor charges of [[Child sexual abuse
column31: child molestation]] and exhibiting pornographic material to a minor were dismissed.<ref name=\"AP no contest\" /> He was sentenced to nine months at a [[drug rehabilitation]] center and three months of [[house arrest]].<ref name=\"nyt\" />

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 1992, Preston was sentenced to 30 days in jail for violating his probation on a drunk driving conviction.<ref name=\"Jet Sentenced\" />
In 1997, Preston was sentenced to three years in a California prison for cocaine possession in violation of his probation.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=News Flash: Billy Preston Jailed After Cocaine Arrest
column11: archive-date=}}</ref><ref name=\"nyt\" /> He had been placed on three years probation earlier that year after testing positive for cocaine use; under the terms he agreed to spend 90 days in jail and to remain drug-free.<ref>{{Cite magazine
column15: title=Billy Preston Sentenced To Three Years In Prison For Violating Porbation On Cocaine Possession

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: While in prison in 1998, Preston was indicted for a $1 million [[insurance fraud]] after setting fire to his own house in Los Angeles.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Billy Preston Indicted in Alleged Insurance Scam
column11: archive-date=}}</ref><ref name=\"nyt\" /> He pleaded guilty and agreed to testify against other defendants involved in the scam.<ref name=\"AP Guilty Fraud\">{{Cite web
column20: archive-date=}}</ref> His plea called for five years of probation, one year in jail, and $60,000 in restitution. The probation and jail time ran concurrent with his cocaine possession conviction.<ref name=\"AP Guilty Fraud\" />

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston had suffered [[kidney disease]] in his later years, brought on by his [[hypertension]]. He received a kidney transplant in 2002, but his health continued to deteriorate. He had voluntarily entered a drug rehabilitation clinic in [[Malibu, California]], at the suggestion of guitarist Is'real Benton, and suffered [[pericarditis]] there, leading to respiratory failure that left him in a coma from November 21, 2005.<ref name=nytobit>{{cite news
column6: title=Billy Preston, 59, Soul Musician, Is Dead; Renowned Keyboardist and Collaborator
column8: quote=Billy Preston, the splashy gospel-rooted keyboardist whose career included No. 1 solo hits and work with the Beatles and the Rolling Stones, died yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 59.
column11: accessdate=2008-06-28 }}</ref> Preston died on June 6, 2006, in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]].<ref name=\"nyt\" />

His song \"[[Nothing from Nothing (Billy Preston song)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Nothing from Nothing]]\" was featured in the soundtrack of the 2008 film ''[[Be Kind Rewind]]''.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: '''William Everett Preston''' (September 2, 1946 – June 6, 2006)<ref name=\"nyt\" /> was an American musician whose work encompassed [[Rhythm and blues
column5: gospel]]. Preston was a top session keyboardist in the 1960s, during which he backed artists such as [[Little Richard]], [[Sam Cooke]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Rev. James Cleveland]] and [[the Beatles]]. He went on to achieve fame as a solo artist, with hit singles such as \"[[That's the Way God Planned It (song)
column6: That's the Way God Planned It]]\", the Grammy-winning \"[[Outa-Space]]\", \"[[Will It Go Round in Circles]]\", \"[[Space Race (Billy Preston song)
column7: Space Race]]\", \"[[Nothing from Nothing (Billy Preston song)
column8: Nothing from Nothing]]\" and \"[[With You I'm Born Again]]\". Additionally, Preston co-wrote \"[[You Are So Beautiful]]\", which became a number 5 hit for [[Joe Cocker]].

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston was one of five musicians<ref>{{Cite AV media notes
column7: id = PCS7009 }} </ref> credited on a Beatles recording other than the group's four members. Preston continued to record and perform with other artists, notably [[George Harrison]] after the Beatles' breakup, and [[Eric Clapton]], and he played keyboards for [[the Rolling Stones]] on many of the group's albums and tours during the 1970s.

column4: p=741}} and moved to [[Los Angeles]] as a child with his mother, Robbie Lee Williams.  Noted as a [[child prodigy]], Preston was entirely self-taught and never had a music lesson. By the age of ten, he was playing [[Organ_(music)
column5: organ]] onstage backing several gospel singers such as [[Mahalia Jackson]].<ref name=\"nyt\">{{cite news
column7: title=Billy Preston, 59, Soul Musician, Is Dead; Renowned Keyboardist and Collaborator
column12: accessdate=February 22, 2019}}</ref> Aged 11, Preston appeared on an episode of [[Nat King Cole]]'s [[NBC]] network TV show singing the [[Fats Domino]] hit \"[[Blueberry Hill (song)
column15: title=billy preston blueberry hill - Bing video
column17: accessdate=28 October 2017}}</ref> He also appeared in ''[[St. Louis Blues (1958 film)
column18: St. Louis Blues]]'', the 1958 [[W. C. Handy]] biopic starring [[Nat King Cole]]; Preston played Handy at a younger age.<ref name=\"nyt\" />

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 1962, Preston joined [[Little Richard]]'s band as an organist, and it was while performing in [[Hamburg]] that he met the Beatles.<ref name=nyt/> In 1963, he played the organ on [[Sam Cooke]]'s ''[[Night Beat (Sam Cooke album)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Night Beat]]'' album and released his own debut album, ''16 Yr Old Soul'', for Cooke's [[SAR Records
column9: title=Billy Preston's ''16-Year-Old Soul'' to be Digitally re-re-released on February 22, 2011 }} \"''16 Year Old Soul'' is an album of percolating organ-infused instrumentals that offers insight into the roots of one of the music world's most innovative and genre-busting stars who died at the age of 59, in 2006. With songs covering a broad spectrum of styles from country ('Born to Loose') to R&B ('Good News') to jazz ('God Bless The Child') with pop and blues undertones aplenty, ''16 Year Old Soul'' is a preserved-in-amber glimpse of an artist whose musical maturity belied his years.\"</ref> In 1965, he released the album ''[[The Most Exciting Organ Ever]]'' and performed on the rock and roll show ''[[Shindig!]]'' In 1967, he joined [[Ray Charles]]' band.{{sfn
column12: p=741}} Following this exposure, several musicians began asking Preston to contribute to their sessions.<ref name=nyt/>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston first met [[the Beatles]] as a 16-year-old in 1962, while part of Little Richard's touring band, when their manager [[Brian Epstein]] organized a Liverpool show, at which the Beatles opened. ''[[The Washington Post]]'' explained their subsequent meeting:

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: They'd hook up again in 1969, when the Beatles were about to break up while recording the last album they released, ''[[Let It Be (Beatles album)
column3: Let It Be]]'' (they would later record ''[[Abbey Road]]'', which was released prior to ''Let It Be''). [[George Harrison]], a friend of Preston, had quit, walked out of the studio and gone to a Ray Charles concert in [[London]], where Preston was playing organ. Harrison brought Preston back to the studio, where his keen musicianship and gregarious personality temporarily calmed the tension.<ref name=\"WP Obit\">{{cite news
column6: title='Fifth Beatle' Billy Preston Made the Greats Even Greater

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston is one of several people referred to as the \"[[Fifth Beatle]]\". At one point during the [[Let It Be (Beatles album)#Recording and production
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: ''Get Back'' sessions]], [[John Lennon]] proposed the idea of having him join the band (to which [[Paul McCartney]] countered that it was difficult enough reaching agreements with four).<ref>The Beatles - A/B Road: The Complete Get back Sessions, January 24th</ref> Preston played organ and electric piano for the Beatles during several of the ''Get Back'' sessions; some of these sessions appeared in the film ''[[Let It Be (1970 film)
column3: Let it Be]]'' and on its companion album. Preston also accompanied the band on electric piano for [[The Beatles' rooftop concert
column4: its rooftop concert]], the group's final public appearance.<ref name=\"WP Obit\"/> In April 1969, their single \"Get Back\" was credited to \"The Beatles with Billy Preston\", the only time such a joint credit had been given on an official Beatles-sanctioned release (as distinct from an unsanctioned reissue of some Hamburg-era recordings on which they were the backing group for [[Tony Sheridan]]). The credit was bestowed by the Beatles to reflect the extent of Preston's presence on the track; his electric piano is prominent throughout and he plays an extended solo. Preston also worked, in a more limited role, on the ''Abbey Road'' album, contributing organ to the tracks \"[[I Want You (She's So Heavy)]]\" and \"[[Something (Beatles song)

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 1978, he appeared as Sgt. Pepper in [[Robert Stigwood]]'s film ''[[Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (film)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band]]'', which was based on the Beatles' [[Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band
column3: album of the same name]], and sang and danced to \"Get Back\" as the penultimate song.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Screen: Son of 'Sgt. Pepper':Many Forms Involved
Preston singing at the piano in 1971]]

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Apple]] label, in 1969, Preston released the album ''[[That's the Way God Planned It]]'', produced by Harrison, the [[That's the Way God Planned It (song)
column3: title song from which]] was a hit single in Britain. His relationship with Harrison continued after the Beatles' break-up in 1970; Preston was the first artist to record Harrison's subsequent international hit \"[[My Sweet Lord]]\", on his 1970 album ''[[Encouraging Words]]'', which Harrison co-produced with him. He appeared on several of Harrison's 1970s solo albums, starting with ''[[All Things Must Pass]]''; made a notable contribution to [[the Concert for Bangladesh]], the Harrison-organized 1971 charity benefit; performed with the ex-Beatle on his 1974 tour of [[North America]]; and played at the 2002 [[Concert for George]] tribute, held at London's [[Royal Albert Hall]]. Preston also worked on solo releases by Lennon and [[Ringo Starr]].

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 1971, Preston left Apple and signed with [[Herb Alpert]]'s [[A&M Records]]. The previous year, he contributed to another hit single when [[Stephen Stills]] asked to use Preston's phrase \"if you can't be with the one you love, [[Love the One You're With
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: love the one you're with]]\", a song on Stills' [[Stephen Stills (album)
column4: title=Song Stories: Love The One You're With

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Following the release of ''[[I Wrote a Simple Song]]'' on A&M, Preston's solo career peaked at this time, beginning with 1972's \"[[Outa-Space]]\", an [[instrumental]] track that further popularized the sound of the [[clavinet]] in [[funk]] music. The song reached number 2 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100
column4: R&B]] chart, before going on to win the [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Instrumental Performance]]. \"Outa-Space\" sold over 1 million copies in America, and was awarded a [[music recording sales certification
column5: gold disc]] by the [[RIAA]] in June 1972.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\">{{cite book
column16: url=https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/319 }}</ref> Later that year, Preston contributed the title song to the hit [[blaxploitation]] film ''[[Slaughter (1972 film)
column17: Slaughter]]'' starring [[Jim Brown]].<ref>{{cite AV media notes
column21: title=[[I Wrote a Simple Song]]/[[Music Is My Life]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Over the next two years, Preston followed up with the US chart-topping singles \"[[Will It Go Round in Circles]]\" (which displaced Harrison's \"[[Give Me Love (Give Me Peace on Earth)]]\" at the top on 7 July 1973) and \"[[Nothing from Nothing (Billy Preston song)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Nothing from Nothing]]\", and the number 4 hit \"[[Space Race (Billy Preston song)
column3: Space Race]]\". Each of the three singles sold in excess of 1 million copies.<ref name=\"The Book of Golden Discs\"/> ''[[American Bandstand]]'' host and executive producer [[Dick Clark]] enjoyed \"Space Race\" so much that he used the instrumental for the mid-show break for virtually the remainder of its run.

column5: Preston (seated behind grand piano in foreground) performing with the Rolling Stones in 1975]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: From 1970, Preston played keyboards (including piano, organ, clavinet and various synthesizers) for [[the Rolling Stones]], sometimes alongside pianists [[Nicky Hopkins]] and [[Ian Stewart (musician)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Ian Stewart]], on their albums ''[[Sticky Fingers]]'', ''[[Exile on Main St.]]'', ''[[Goats Head Soup]]'', ''[[It's Only Rock 'n Roll]]'' and ''[[Black and Blue]]''. As the band's primary touring keyboardist from 1973 to 1977, he also performed as a support act with his own band (including [[Mick Taylor]] on guitar) on their [[The Rolling Stones 1973 European Tour
column3: 1973 European tour]]. A [[Munich]] performance from this tour was documented on Preston's album ''[[Live European Tour 1973]]''. In 1974, along with [[Bruce Fisher]], one of his regular songwriting collaborators in the 1970s, he composed one of Joe Cocker's biggest hits, \"[[You Are So Beautiful]]\". On October 11, 1975, he was the first musical guest on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''{{'}}s series premiere episode.<ref name=nyt/> Preston's 1973 song \"Do You Love Me\" was the basis for the Rolling Stones' track \"Melody\", released on ''Black and Blue'' in 1976. Although two of his songs were included in the band's 1975 and 1976 live sets, the Stones and Preston parted company in 1977, mainly due to a disagreement over money. He continued to play on solo records by Stones members like [[Mick Jagger]]'s ''[[Wandering Spirit (album)
column4: Wandering Spirit]]'', and made appearances on the band's ''[[Tattoo You]]'' and ''[[Bridges to Babylon]]''.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: After seven years with A&M, he signed with [[Motown]]. In 1979, he duetted with [[Syreeta Wright]] on the ballad \"[[With You I'm Born Again]]\",<ref name=nyt/> which reached number 4 on the charts in the US. Preston's career lost momentum in the 1980s due to his [[cocaine]] and alcohol addictions. He left Motown in 1984 and focused on session work, contributing to works by artists such as [[Luther Vandross]] (his organ solos were included on Vandross' 1985 hit \"Til My Baby Comes Home\"), [[Whitney Houston]] and [[Patti LaBelle]], among others. He served as musical director for ''[[Nightlife (TV series)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Nightlife]]'', a late-night [[talk show]] hosted by [[David Brenner]] that lasted one season from 1986 to 1987.<ref name=\"Chase\">
title=He's On His Own In Late-night TV

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston toured with [[Eric Clapton]], recorded with Gary Walker, one of the vocalists in his Los Angeles-based band, and worked with a wide range of other artists. He also toured with [[Ringo Starr]], appearing on [[Ringo Starr and His All-Starr Band
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: his 1990 live album]]. He was invited to become a member of [[The Band]] in 1991, after the death of piano player [[Stan Szelest]]. He performed on tour with the group,<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Billy Preston Makes The Band Born Again
column13: access-date=2019-11-05}}</ref> but the sentencing from his cocaine and sexual assault charges in 1991 ended the collaboration.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 1997, Billy Preston recorded the album ''You and I'', in Italy, with Italian band [[Novecento (group)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Novecento]]. The album was produced by Vaughn De Spenza and Novecento members [[Nicolosi Productions
column8: accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> In 1998, Preston played organ during the choir numbers on the [[UPN]] comedy show ''[[Good News (TV series)
column9: Good News]]''. The same year he sang and played synthesizer in the film ''[[Blues Brothers 2000]]'', as part of [[the Louisiana Gator Boys]] supergroup.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: On November 29, 2001, while touring and fighting his own health problems, Preston received the news that George Harrison had died, having long suffered from [[Head and neck cancer
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: throat cancer]]. Preston, among many of Harrison's longtime friends, performed in the 2002 [[Concert for George]] at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in London. Preston's performance of \"My Sweet Lord\" received critical acclaim. Additionally, he sang \"[[Isn't It a Pity]]\", provided backing vocals on most of the other songs, and played the [[Hammond organ]] for the show.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 2002, Preston appeared on the [[Johnny Cash]] album ''[[American IV: The Man Comes Around]]'', playing piano on \"[[Personal Jesus]]\" and \"[[Tear-Stained Letter]]\".

In 2004, Preston toured with [[the Funk Brothers]] and [[Steve Winwood]] in Europe, and then with Clapton in Europe and North America. After the Clapton tours, he went to France, where he was featured in one episode of the ''Legends Rock TV Show.''<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Guest Artist of the Legends Rock TV Show
column6: accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> His performance included a duet with [[Sam Moore]] on \"You Are So Beautiful\"; this was Preston's last filmed concert.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 2004, Preston performed as a [[List of jazz organists
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: jazz organist]] on Ray Charles' ''[[Genius Loves Company]]'', an album of duets, on the song \"[[Here We Go Again (Ray Charles song)
column3: Here We Go Again]]\" with Charles and [[Norah Jones]].

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In March 2005, he appeared on the ''[[American Idol]]'' [[American Idol (season 4)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: fourth season]] finale. Playing piano, he performed \"[[With You I'm Born Again]]\" with [[Vonzell Solomon]] (who finished the contest in third place). The same year, he recorded \"Go Where No One's Gone Before\", the main title song for the [[anime]] series ''[[L/R: Licensed by Royalty]]''.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston played [[clavinet]] on the song \"Warlocks\" for the [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]] album ''[[Stadium Arcadium]]'' (2006). Although very ill by this point, he jumped out of his bed after hearing a tape of the song given to him by the band, recorded his part, and went back to bed.<ref>{{cite magazine
column3: title=Red Hot Chili Peppers - Peppers Get Sick Preston Out Of Bed
column5: accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> Preston's final recorded contributions were the gospel-tinged organ on the [[Neil Diamond]] album ''[[12 Songs (Neil Diamond album)
column6: 12 Songs]]'' (2005), and his keyboard work on ''[[The Road to Escondido]]'' (2006) by Eric Clapton and [[J. J. Cale]].

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In late 2005, Preston made his last public performance, in Los Angeles, to publicize the re-release of the 1972  documentary film ''[[The Concert for Bangladesh (film)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: The Concert for Bangladesh]]''. He played a set of three Harrison songs – \"Give Me Love\", \"My Sweet Lord\" and \"Isn't It a Pity\" – with [[Dhani Harrison]] and Starr joining on guitar and drums, respectively, for the last song.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston lived in [[London]] for a time,<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=28 October 2017}}</ref> possibly around 1969–1971, but he moved back to the US sometime in the early 1970s.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Billy Preston was brought up in the African-American [[Gospel music
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: gospel]] tradition; he was a committed Christian throughout his life and he openly expressed his faith in works such as his 1970s hit \"[[That's the Way God Planned It (song)
column3: That's the Way God Planned It]]\". However, his personal beliefs were sometimes at odds with the attitudes and musical expressions of the secular world of rock & roll in which he often worked; while he was apparently willing to put his religious views aside when working on tracks like [[John Lennon]]'s openly atheistic song \"[[God (John Lennon song)
column4: God]]\". Preston was also deeply attached to his mother, for whom he wrote the song that became his best-known composition, \"[[You Are So Beautiful]]\".<ref name=\"bbc.co.uk\">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00wqb5d ''Billy Preston: That's The Way God Planned It''], BBC Radio 4,  December 21, 2010.</ref>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Although the details did not become fully known to the general public until after his death, Preston struggled throughout his life to cope with his [[homosexuality]], and the lasting effects of the traumatic sexual abuse he suffered as a boy. Although his [[sexual orientation]] became known to friends and associates in the music world (such as [[Keith Richards]]), Preston did not publicly come out as gay until just before he died. This was reportedly partly because he felt that it conflicted with his deeply held religious beliefs and his lifelong association with the church, so he remained \"[[Coming out
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: in the closet]]\" until shortly before his death. Keith Richards' autobiography, ''Life'',<ref>{{cite book
column10: quote=And he was gay at a time when nobody could be openly gay, which added difficulties to his life. Billy could be, most of time, a bundle of fun. but sometimes he would get on the rag. I had to stop him from beating up his boyfriend in an elevator once.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
column28: date=July 25, 2011}}</ref> mentions Billy Preston's struggles with his sexuality.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In an interview for a 2010 [[BBC Radio 4]] documentary on his life and career, Preston's manager Joyce Moore revealed that after she began handling his affairs, Preston opened up to her about the lifelong trauma he had suffered as the result of being sexually abused as a boy. Preston told Moore that at about the age of nine, after he and his mother moved to Los Angeles from Houston to perform in a touring production of ''[[Amos 'n' Andy]]'', he was repeatedly abused by the touring company's pianist. When Preston told his mother about the abuse, she did not believe him, and failed to protect him.<ref name=\"bbc.co.uk\" /> The abuse subsequently went on for the entire summer, and Preston stated that he was also later abused by a local pastor.

Another traumatic incident, which reportedly affected Preston deeply, occurred in the early 1970s, while he was engaged to actress/model Kathy Silva. At this time Preston had become close friends with musician [[Sly Stone]], and made many contributions to Stone's recordings of the period (including the landmark album ''[[There's a Riot Goin' On]]''). According to Moore, Preston was devastated when he came home one day to find Stone in bed with Silva (who later famously married Stone on stage at Madison Square Garden). According to Moore, Silva's affair with Stone was the trigger that led Preston to stop having relationships with women. It was after this incident that he began abusing [[cocaine]] and having sex with men, and Moore has stated that she saw his drug abuse as his way of coping with the internal conflicts he felt about his sexual urges.<ref name=\"bbc.co.uk\"/><ref>[http://www.houstonpress.com/music/the-bitter-battle-over-fifth-beatle-billy-prestons-estate-6779599 Nate Jackson, \"The Bitter Battle over 'Fifth Beatle' Billy Preston's Estate\", ''Houston Press'', March 11, 2015 (retrieved December 1, 2015)]</ref>
In 1991, Preston checked into a drug rehabilitation program to treat his addictions.<ref>{{Cite magazine
column5: title=Singer Billy Preston To Seek Drug Treatment

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: drunk driving]] conviction in August 1991,<ref name=\"Jet Sentenced\">{{Cite magazine
column6: title=Billy Preston Sentenced To 30 Days In Jail
column11: via=}}</ref> Preston was arrested for sexually assaulting a 16-year-old Mexican boy, after picking him up at a gathering point for day laborers.<ref>{{Cite news
column13: title=Singer Billy Preston Arrested in Sex Case
column18: access-date=}}</ref> The boy told authorities that Preston took him to his Malibu home, smoked cocaine, showed him [[Pornography
column19: pornographic]] pictures and tried to assault him before he escaped.<ref name=\"AP no contest\">{{Cite web
column21: title=Musician Billy Preston Pleads No Contest to Assault and Drug Charges
column28: archive-date=}}</ref> Preston was also charged with [[Assault
column29: assault with a deadly weapon]] involving a man he picked up to do work at his home, the day before his arrest in the case involving the boy.<ref name=\"AP no contest\" /> After submitting to a drug test, Preston tested positive for cocaine. He entered [[nolo contendre
column30: no-contest pleas]] to the cocaine and assault charges. The sex charges which included misdemeanor charges of [[Child sexual abuse
column31: child molestation]] and exhibiting pornographic material to a minor were dismissed.<ref name=\"AP no contest\" /> He was sentenced to nine months at a [[drug rehabilitation]] center and three months of [[house arrest]].<ref name=\"nyt\" />

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In 1992, Preston was sentenced to 30 days in jail for violating his probation on a drunk driving conviction.<ref name=\"Jet Sentenced\" />
In 1997, Preston was sentenced to three years in a California prison for cocaine possession in violation of his probation.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=News Flash: Billy Preston Jailed After Cocaine Arrest
column11: archive-date=}}</ref><ref name=\"nyt\" /> He had been placed on three years probation earlier that year after testing positive for cocaine use; under the terms he agreed to spend 90 days in jail and to remain drug-free.<ref>{{Cite magazine
column15: title=Billy Preston Sentenced To Three Years In Prison For Violating Porbation On Cocaine Possession

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: While in prison in 1998, Preston was indicted for a $1 million [[insurance fraud]] after setting fire to his own house in Los Angeles.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Billy Preston Indicted in Alleged Insurance Scam
column11: archive-date=}}</ref><ref name=\"nyt\" /> He pleaded guilty and agreed to testify against other defendants involved in the scam.<ref name=\"AP Guilty Fraud\">{{Cite web
column20: archive-date=}}</ref> His plea called for five years of probation, one year in jail, and $60,000 in restitution. The probation and jail time ran concurrent with his cocaine possession conviction.<ref name=\"AP Guilty Fraud\" />

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Preston had suffered [[kidney disease]] in his later years, brought on by his [[hypertension]]. He received a kidney transplant in 2002, but his health continued to deteriorate. He had voluntarily entered a drug rehabilitation clinic in [[Malibu, California]], at the suggestion of guitarist Is'real Benton, and suffered [[pericarditis]] there, leading to respiratory failure that left him in a coma from November 21, 2005.<ref name=nytobit>{{cite news
column6: title=Billy Preston, 59, Soul Musician, Is Dead; Renowned Keyboardist and Collaborator
column8: quote=Billy Preston, the splashy gospel-rooted keyboardist whose career included No. 1 solo hits and work with the Beatles and the Rolling Stones, died yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 59.
column11: accessdate=2008-06-28 }}</ref> Preston died on June 6, 2006, in [[Scottsdale, Arizona]].<ref name=\"nyt\" />

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The '''Canada lynx''' (''Lynx canadensis'') is a medium-sized [[lynx]] native to [[North America]]. It ranges across [[Canada]] and [[Alaska]] extending into the United States portion of the [[Rocky Mountains]]. It is characterized by its long, dense fur, triangular ears with black tufts at the tips, and broad, [[snowshoe]]-like paws. Similar to the [[bobcat]] (''L. rufus''), the hindlimbs are remarkably longer than the forelimbs, so that the back appears to be sloping downward to the front. The lynx is a good swimmer and an agile climber. The Canada lynx stands {{convert
column7: abbr=on}} tall at the shoulder and weighs between {{convert
column13: abbr=on}}. This lynx was first [[scientific description
column15: Robert Kerr]] in 1792. Three [[subspecies]] are recognized.

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: nocturnal]] like its primary prey, the [[snowshoe hare]]. The strong dependence of this [[Specialist and generalist species
column3: specialist predator]] on snowshoe hares for food leads to an example of a prey-predator cycle. Canada lynxes respond to the cyclic rises and falls over the years in snowshoe hare populations in Alaska and central Canada—when hares are scarce lynxes tend to move to areas with more hares and tend to not produce litters, and as the numbers of the hare increase, so does the population of the lynx. The lynx waits for the hare in specific trails or \"ambush beds\", then pounces on it and kills it by a bite on its head, throat or the nape of its neck. Individuals of the same sex particularly tend to avoid each other, forming \"intrasexual\" territories. The mating season is roughly a month long (from March to early April). After a gestational period of two to three months, a litter of one to eight kittens is born. Offspring are weaned at 12 weeks.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: This lynx occurs predominantly in dense [[Taiga
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: boreal forest]]s, and its range heavily coincides with that of the snowshoe hare. Given its abundance throughout its range and no severe threats, this lynx has been listed as [[Least Concern]] on the [[IUCN Red List]]. This lynx is regularly trapped for the international fur trade in most of Alaska and Canada, but is protected in the southern half of its range due to threats such as habitat loss.

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: In his 1792 work ''The Animal Kingdom'', Scottish scientific writer [[Robert Kerr (writer)
column4: lynx]] from Canada, giving it the [[Binomial nomenclature
column16: taxonomy]] of the Canada lynx remained disputed through the 20th and early 21st centuries. In 1912, American zoologist [[Gerrit Miller]] placed the Canada lynx under the [[Genus (biology)
column17: genus]] ''Lynx'', with the name ''L. canadensis''.<ref>{{cite book
column21: title=List of North American land mammals in the United States National Museum, 1911
column26: date = 1912}}</ref> Until as late as the early 2000s, scientists were divided on whether ''Lynx'' should be considered a [[Subgenus (biology)
column28: subfamily]] itself; some even doubted if the Canada lynx should be considered a species on its own.<ref name=Tumlison>{{cite journal
column43: title=The Scientific Basis for Conserving Forest Carnivores: American Marten, Fisher, Lynx and Wolverine in the Western United States
column69: title=Wild Mammals of North America: Biology, Management, and Conservation
column79: W. C. Wozencraft]] revised the classification of [[Carnivora]] in 2005, and recognized the Canada lynx as a species under ''Lynx'', along with the [[bobcat]] (''L. rufus''), the [[Eurasian lynx]] (''L. lynx'') and the [[Iberian lynx]] (''L. pardinus''). In 2017, the Cat Classification Task Force of the [[IUCN]] Cat Specialist Group revised felid taxonomy, considering the Canada lynx a [[monotypic species]].<ref name=\"Catsg2017\">{{cite journal
column104: title=A revised taxonomy of the Felidae: The final report of the Cat Classification Task Force of the IUCN Cat Specialist Group
column108: url=https://repository.si.edu/bitstream/handle/10088/32616/A_revised_Felidae_Taxonomy_CatNews.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y}}</ref><!--this is not about taxonomy: <ref name=CanLynx>{{cite report

Noting only a few differences between the two forms, the study suggested the Newfoundland lynx to have [[genetic divergence

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: According to a 2006 [[phylogenetic]] study, the ancestor of five felid lineages – ''Lynx'', ''Leopardus'', ''Puma'', ''Felis'' and ''[[Prionailurus]]'' plus ''[[Otocolobus]]'' – arrived in North America after crossing the [[Bering Strait]] 8.5–8 [[Mya (unit)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: mya]]. ''Lynx'' diverged from the ''Puma'', ''Felis'' and ''Prionailurus'' plus ''Otocolobus'' lineages around 3.24 mya.<ref name=Johnson2006/> The [[Issoire lynx]] (''L. issiodorensis''), that probably originated in Africa 4 mya and occurred in Europe and northern Asia until it fell to extinction around 1 mya, is believed to be the ancestor of the four modern species of ''Lynx''.<ref name=\"Sunquist\">{{cite book
column20: title=The lynx from Etouaires, ''Lynx issiodorensis'' (Croizet & Jobert), Late Pliocene
column27: url=http://www.sekj.org/PDF/anzf15/anzf15-314-322.pdf}}</ref> A 1987 study suggested that the populations of the Eurasian lynx that reached North America 20,000 years ago initially settled in the southern half of the continent, as the northern part was covered by glaciers. The southern populations gradually evolved into the modern bobcat. Later, when the continent was invaded by the Eurasian lynx for a second time, the populations that settled in the northern part of the continent, now devoid of glaciers, evolved into the Canada lynx.<ref name=\"Quinn1987\">{{cite book
column38: title= Furbearer Management and Conservation in North America
column44: isbn=978-0-7743-9365-2}}</ref> The 2006 study gave the phylogenetic relationships of the Canada lynx as follows:<ref name=Johnson2006>{{cite journal
column55: title = The Late Miocene radiation of modern Felidae: A genetic assessment
column62: bibcode = 2006Sci...311...73J
column81: title=Biology and Conservation of Wild Felids

column3: A close facial view of the Canada lynx. The black ear tufts are characteristic of lynxes.]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The Canada lynx is a lean, medium-sized cat characterized by its long, dense fur, triangular ears with black tufts at the tips, and broad, [[snowshoe]]-like paws. Similar to the bobcat, the hindlimbs are remarkably longer than the forelimbs, so that the back appears to be sloping downward to the front. The Canada lynx is [[sexually dimorphic]], with males larger and heavier than females. The lynx is between {{convert
column7: abbr=on}} in head-and-body length and stands {{convert
column13: abbr=on}} tall at the shoulder; females weigh around {{convert
column25: abbr=on}}.<ref name=Sunquist/> Physical proportions do not vary significantly across the range and are probably [[natural selection
column26: naturally selected]] to allow survival on smaller prey.<ref>{{cite journal
column41: url-status=dead}}</ref> The Eurasian lynx, that prefers prey the size of a [[roe deer]], is twice the size of the Canada lynx, that feeds primarily on the [[snowshoe hare]].<ref name=Sunquist/> The stubby tail, typical of lynxes, is {{convert
column47: abbr=on}} long; while the bobcat's tail is black only in the upper part, the tail of the Canada lynx has a completely black tip.<ref name=Sunquist/><ref name=Hunter>{{cite book

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The long, dense fur, uniformly coloured with little to no markings except on the underside, insulates the lynx in its frosty habitat. The fur is typically yellowish brown, though in Newfoundland it can vary from brown or buff-gray in spring and summer to a grayish shade with a grizzled appearance in winter; the underparts are white and may have a few dark spots.<ref name=\"Nowak\">{{cite book
column16: albinistic]] forms of the Canada lynx are known, \"blue\" lynxes have been reported in Alaska.<ref>{{cite journal
column19: title=Blue or dilute mutation in Alaskan lynx
column25: doi=10.1093/jmammal/19.3.376-a}}</ref> The fur is generally shorter in summer than in winter.<ref>{{cite book
column28: title=Peterson Field Guide to Mammals of North America
column38: plainurl=yes}}}}</ref> The backs of the ears are brown with a silvery-gray spot at the centre.<ref name=Tumlison/> Similar to other lynxes, black tufts around {{convert
column41: in}} in length emerge from the tips of the ears, which are lined with black fur.<ref name=Hunter/> In winter, the hair on the lower cheek becomes longer, giving the impression of a ruffle covering the throat. There are four nipples.<ref name=Sunquist/><ref name=Nowak/>

column4: As the forelimbs of the Canada lynx are shorter than the hindlimbs, the back appears to be sloping downward toward the front. Note the stubby tail and the dense fur.]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The large, broad paws are covered in long, thick fur and can spread as wide as {{convert
column4: in}} to move fast and easily on soft snow.<ref name=Anderson/> The paws of a Canada lynx can support nearly double the weight those of a bobcat can bear before sinking.<ref name=lox/><ref name=Parker>{{cite journal
column13: title=The ecology of the lynx (''Lynx canadensis'') on Cape Breton Island
column19: doi=10.1139/z83-102}}</ref> Both species walk with the back foot typically following the front foot, and often do not follow a straight line path. The stride is {{convert
column26: order=flip}} for the lynx, while that of the bobcat varies between {{convert
column33: order=flip}}. Canada lynx tracks are generally larger than those of the bobcat; the thicker fur may make the toe pads appear less prominent in the snow. In dirt the tracks of the lynx are {{convert
column47: order=flip}} wide, whereas in snow they are bigger ({{convert
column57: order=flip}} wide).<ref name = golden/><ref name=\"yukongov\">{{cite report
column61: publisher=Government of Yukon}}</ref> The warm coat, wide paws and long legs serve as adaptations for the lynx to efficiently navigate and hunt in snow.<ref name=lox/>

column4: Canada lynx tracks in Alaska, with traces of fur]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The Canada lynx has 28 teeth,<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=A Field Guide to the Mammals: North America North of Mexico
column14: plainurl=yes}}}}</ref> same as in other lynxes but unlike other felids that have 30,<ref name=Anderson/> with four long [[canine tooth
column15: canines]] for puncturing and gripping. The lynx can feel where it is biting the prey with its canines because they are heavily laced with nerves. It also has four [[carnassial teeth]] that cut the meat into small pieces. In order for the lynx to use its carnassials, it must chew the meat with its head to its side. There are large spaces between the four canines and the rest of the teeth, and the second upper [[premolar]]s are absent, to ensure that the bite goes as deeply as possible into the prey.<ref>{{cite book
column18: title=The Velvet Claw: A Natural History of the Carnivores
column25: url-access=registration}}</ref> The claws are sharp and fully retractable (capable of being drawn within).<ref name=Tumlison/>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The Canada lynx can be told apart from the bobcat by its longer ear tufts, broader paws, shorter tail with a fully black tip, longer legs and the fewer markings and grayer shade of the coat.<ref name=Anderson/><ref name=golden>{{cite web
column6: title=How to avoid incidental take of lynx while trapping or hunting bobcats and other furbearers
column8: publisher=United States Fish & Wildlife Service and International Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies
column17: title=Kaufman Field Guide to Mammals of North America
column26: plainurl=yes}}}}</ref> The bobcat is generally smaller than the Canada lynx, but in areas where they are [[Sympatry
column27: sympatric]] the bobcat tends to be larger and may still be confused with the Canada lynx.<ref name=Hunter/> The [[caracal]] resembles the lynxes in having similar tufts on the ears.<ref name=\"skinner\">{{cite book
column32: title=The Mammals of the Southern African Sub-region

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The Canada lynx tends to be [[nocturnality
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: nocturnal]] like its primary prey, the snowshoe hare. Nevertheless, activity may be observed during daytime.<ref name=Sunquist/> The lynx can cover {{convert
column8: abbr=on}} every day to procure prey,<ref name=Saunders>{{cite journal
column11: title=Movements and activities of the lynx in Newfoundland
column23: title=Hunting activities and success of lynxes in Alberta
column49: title=Functional responses of coyotes and lynx to the snowshoe hare cycle
column56: url=https://www.math.unl.edu/~bdeng1/Teaching/math943/Topics/Data%20Fit/Odon98.pdf}}</ref> Lynxes are good swimmers;<ref name=Nowak/> one account records a lynx swimming {{convert
column62: title= Forest Cats of North America Cougars, Bobcats, Lynx
column69: page=35 }}</ref> Canada lynxes are efficient climbers, and will dodge predators by climbing high up on trees, but they hunt only on the ground.<ref name=Hunter/> These lynxes are primarily solitary, with minimal social interaction except for the bond between mothers and female offspring, and the temporary association between individuals of opposite sexes during the mating season.<ref name=Parker/><ref>{{cite journal
column74: title=Observations on home range sizes, movements, and social organization of lynx, (''Lynx canadensis''), in Riding Mountains National Park, Manitoba
column79: url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/275651457}}</ref> Individuals of the same sex particularly tend to avoid each other, forming \"intrasexual\" territories—a social structure similar to that found in bobcats, cougars, [[mustelid]]s and [[ursidae
column80: ursids]]. Intraspecific aggression and consequent cannibalism (more common when food is scarce) are rare.<ref name=ruggiero>{{cite book
column95: title=Ecology and conservation of lynx in the United States (General Technical Report RMRS-GTR-30WWW)
column97: chapter=Ecology of lynx in northern Canada and Alaska
column99: publisher=U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: Fisher]]s are known to occasionally hunt Canada lynxes in the northeastern United States; a study in northern [[Maine]] identified predation by fishers as the leading cause of Canada lynx mortality over 12 years, though it did not appear to affect population growth in the lynxes.<ref>{{cite journal
column13: title=Fisher predation on Canada lynx in the Northeastern United States
column23: title=Small weasel-like animals are taking down big cats

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The Canada lynx is known to host several [[Parasitism

column30: doi=10.1139/z86-057}}</ref> Canada lynxes could have played a role in the transmission of the [[zoonosis

column62: pmid=23307370 }}</ref> A study in 2019 identified a [[gammaherpesvirus]] species in the Canada lynx for the first time. The study discovered a novel [[percavirus]], named LcaGHV1, in [[spleen]] samples of Canada lynxes from Maine and Newfoundland.<ref>{{cite journal
column83: title=Identification of a novel gammaherpesvirus in Canada lynx (''Lynx canadensis'')

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: [[File:Milliers fourrures vendues en environ 90 ans odum 1953 en.jpg
column5: Numbers of [[snowshoe hare]]s (''Lepus americanus'', yellow, background) and Canada lynx (black line, foreground) furs sold to the [[Hudson's Bay Company]]]]

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: specialist predator]], the Canada lynx depends heavily on snowshoe hares for food.<ref name=Hunter/> Snowshoe hare populations in Alaska and central Canada undergo cyclic rises and falls—at times the population densities can fall from as high as {{convert
column10: abbr=on}}. Consequently, a period of hare scarcity occurs every 8 to 11 years. An example of a prey-predator cycle, the cyclic variations in snowshoe hare populations significantly affect the numbers of their predators—lynxes and [[coyote]]s—in the region. When the hare populations plummet, lynxes tend to move to areas with more hares, and tend to not produce litters; as the numbers of the hare increase, so does the population of the lynx.<ref name=\"Brand1979\">{{cite journal
column15: title=Lynx demography during a snowshoe hare decline in Alberta
column31: title=Numerical responses of coyotes and lynx to the snowshoe hare cycle
column43: title=Behavioural responses of lynx to declining snowshoe hare abundance
column49: doi=10.1139/z85-421}}</ref> In northern Canada, the abundance of lynxes can be estimated from the records kept of the number caught each year for their fur; records have been kept by the [[Hudson's Bay Company]] and [[Government of Canada
column60: jstor=2460337}}</ref> These cycles have been cited as one of the few examples of the [[Lotka-Volterra equations
column61: Lotka–Volterra predator–prey equations]], caused by the interplay of three major factors—food, predation and social interaction.<ref name=\"krebs2001\">{{cite journal
column62: last1=Krebs
column70: title=What drives the 10-year cycle of snowshoe hares?: The ten-year cycle of snowshoe hares—one of the most striking features of the boreal forest— is a product of the interaction between predation and food supplies, as large-scale experiments in the Yukon have demonstrated
column77: url=https://academic.oup.com/bioscience/article-pdf/51/1/25/26890541/51-1-25.pdf}}</ref> A study involving statistical modelling of the interspecific relations of the snowshoe hare, the plant species it feeds on and its predators (including the Canada lynx) suggested that while the demographics of the lynx depend primarily on the hare, the hare's dynamics depend both on the plant species in its diet and predators, of which the Canada lynx is just one.<ref>{{cite journal
column86: title=Population regulation in snowshoe hare and Canadian lynx: Asymmetric food web configurations between hare and lynx
column87: journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
column96: url=https://www.pnas.org/content/pnas/94/10/5147.full.pdf}}</ref> Environmental factors such as forest fires, precipitation and snowfall might also significantly affect this prey-predator cycle.<ref>{{cite journal
column99: title=Forest fires and the snowshoe hare-Canada lynx cycle

column3: Lynxes are typically solitary with minimal social bonds.]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Canada lynxes establish [[home range]]s that vary widely in size, depending upon the method of measurement. The two common methods are examining the tracks of the lynx on snow (snow-tracking) and [[Wildlife radio telemetry
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: radio telemetry]]; snow-tracking generally gives smaller sizes for home ranges. Studies based on snow-tracking have estimated home range sizes of {{convert
column8: abbr=on}}, while those based on radio telemetry have given the area between {{convert
column14: abbr=on}}.<ref name=lox/> Like other cats, Canada lynxes [[Territorial marking
column15: scent-mark]] their ranges by spraying urine and depositing faeces on snow or tree stumps and other prominent sites in and around their range.<ref name=Sunquist/>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Factors such as availability of prey (primarily snowshoe hare), density of lynxes and the topography of the habitat determine the shape and size of the home range.<ref name=lox/> Studies have tried to correlate the abundance of snowshoe hares in an area with the sizes of lynx home ranges in that area. A 1985 study showed that the mean size of home ranges trebled—from {{convert
column7: abbr=on}}—when the density of hares fell from {{convert
column18: title=Behavioural responses of lynx to declining snowshoe hare abundance
column24: doi=10.1139/z85-421}}</ref> However, a few other studies have reported different responses from lynxes at times of prey scarcity; some lynxes do not show any changes in their ranges, while others may resort to hunting in small areas, occupying small home ranges.<ref name=lox/> Canada lynxes generally do not leave their home ranges frequently, though limited prey availability can force lynxes to disperse or expand their ranges.<ref name=Poole1995>{{cite journal
column27: title=Spatial organization of a lynx population
column36: title=Dispersal patterns of lynx in the Northwest Territories

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Males tend to occupy larger ranges than do females; for instance, data from a 1980 radio telemetric analysis in [[Minnesota]] showed that home ranges of males spread over {{convert
column7: abbr=on}}, while those of females covered {{convert
column16: title=Age, sex, reproduction, and spatial organization of lynxes colonizing Northeastern Minnesota
column23: doi=10.2307/1380047}}</ref> In another radio telemetric study in 1985 in [[Montana]], male home ranges averaged {{convert
column27: abbr=on}} and those of females averaged {{convert
column34: title=Reproductive ecology of bobcats and lynx in western Montana
column38: pages=1–85}}</ref> In a study in the southern [[Northwest Territories]], ranges of individuals of opposite sexes were found to overlap extensively, while the ranges of individuals of the same sex hardly coincided. The study suggested that individuals do not show any significant tendency to avoid or mingle with one another, and thus only passively defend their ranges.<ref name=Poole1995/> Female home ranges contract in size when the females have offspring to take care of, and expand to their original size at the time of weaning.<ref name=ruggiero/>

1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: genetic]] study showed that lynxes at the periphery of a population, given their smaller numbers and greater susceptibility to variations in the range, face more difficulty in breeding with lynxes toward the centre of the population and hence show lower [[genetic variability]].<ref>{{cite journal
column13: title=Landscape location affects genetic variation of Canada lynx (''Lynx canadensis'')

column4: [[Snowshoe hare]], the primary prey of the Canada lynx]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The Canada lynx preys primarily and almost exclusively on the snowshoe hare. These hares comprise 35–97% of their diet; the proportion varies by the season and the abundance of hares.<ref name=Hunter/> However, at times when the numbers of the hare drop, lynxes will include other animals in their diet—such as ducks, [[grouse]], moles, [[ptarmigan]], [[red squirrel]]s, voles and young [[ungulate]]s ([[Dall's sheep]], [[mule deer]] and [[boreal woodland caribou
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: caribou]])—though snowshoe hares continue to be the primary component. The Canada lynx tends to be less selective in summer and autumn, adding small mammals as a minor component of their diet besides the hare. The reason behind this is unclear—it could be due to greater abundance of alternate prey, or reduced success in hunting hares.<ref name=ruggiero/> A study in Alaska found that lynxes played a role in the decrease in populations of [[red fox]], caribou and Dall's sheep when hares were very low in number.<ref>{{cite journal
column9: title=Lynx, ''Felis lynx'', predation on red foxes, ''Vulpes vulpes'', caribou, ''Rangifer tarandus'', and Dall sheep, ''Ovis dalli'', in Alaska
column19: lb}} of food everyday.<ref name=Sunquist/><ref name=Hunter/> Lynxes have also been reported feeding occasionally on [[Succulent plant

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Canadian lynxes hunt around twilight or at night, the time when snowshoe hares tend to be active.<ref name=Hunter/> Lynxes rely on their vision and sense of hearing to locate prey.<ref name=Nowak/> The lynx will roam or wait (in what researchers often term \"ambush beds\") on certain trails where snowshoe hares gather, pounce on a hare and kill it by a bite on its head, throat or the nape of its neck.<ref name=ruggiero/> Sometimes a chase of around ten bounds may be necessary to trap the prey. The lynx is assisted by its [[Stereopsis
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: stereoscopic vision]] in detecting prey and measuring distances. Staying in cover while hunting helps the lynx conserve energy in its frigid habitat by avoiding unnecessary movement.<ref name=yukongov/> Young ungulates are given a throat bite to suffocate them to death. The lynx may eat its kill immediately or cache it in snow or leaves to eat it over the next few days.<ref name=Sunquist/><ref name=Hunter/><ref name=ruggiero/> Studies suggest success in hunting hares depends heavily on the distance between the lynx and the hare when the lynx starts chasing it and their relative speeds, which in turn depends on the hunting prowess of the lynx, the alertness of the hare and the vegetation cover among other factors.<ref name=Sunquist/> Lynxes will occasionally hunt together, though studies differ on how this affects the hunting success rate compared to when an individual hunts alone.<ref name=ruggiero/> In fact, they may hunt in groups when hares are scarce.<ref name = dono98/> [[Scavenger
column3: Scavenging]] is common in Canada lynxes; they will take ungulates killed by the cold or vehicles.<ref name=Hunter/>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Both coyotes and Canada lynxes are major predators of the snowshoe hare. A study showed that compared to lynxes, the feet of coyotes sink deeper in the snow due to their smaller size and hence a larger body mass to foot area ratio, prompting them to ambush their prey instead of chasing it like lynxes often do.<ref name=\"murray1991\">{{cite journal
column6: title=The influence of snow on lynx and coyote movements: does morphology affect behavior?
column14: bibcode=1991Oecol..88..463M }}</ref> A study of the two species in southwest [[Yukon Territory]] showed that when the numbers of the hare increased, both predators killed more hares than were necessary for their subsistence; lynxes need to kill 0.4 to 0.5 hare per day to meet their energy requirements, but were observed to kill 1.2 hares per day during this period. Coyotes, with a success rate of 36.9%, emerged as more successful hunters than lynxes that succeeded in 28.7% of their hunts; however this may have resulted from the greater number of adult coyotes in the studied population. Lynxes rarely cached their kills, unlike coyotes, and this may have led to incomplete consumption of some kills. During the cyclic decrease in snowshoe hare numbers, both predators hunted for the same time period as they did when hares were abundant, but lynxes killed more hares than they did earlier. Moreover, lynxes supplemented their diet with red squirrels.<ref name=ODonoghue/><ref name=dono98>{{cite journal
column25: title=Behavioural responses of coyote and lynx to the snowshoe hare cycle

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The mating season is roughly a month long, from March to early April. Urine marking and mating calls are part of [[Display (zoology)
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: display behaviour]], and increases the interaction between individuals of opposite sexes. Females can be [[Induced ovulation (animals)
column3: induced ovulators]] when the availability of mates is low, or spontaneous ovulators when several mates are available. Females have only a single [[estrus cycle]]; estrus lasts for three to five days in captivity.<ref name=Sunquist /> Individuals have been observed making long wailing vocalizations, probably as mating calls.<ref>{{cite journal
column8: title=Some observations on the natural history and behaviour of the Canada Lynx, ''Lynx canadensis''
column14: url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Brian_Slough/publication/268872103_Some_observations_on_the_natural_history_and_behaviour_of_the_Canada_Lynx_Lynx_canadensis/links/547a2cbc0cf293e2da2b5e05.pdf}}</ref> Before birth, the female prepares a maternal den, usually in very thick brush, and typically inside thickets of shrubs, trees or woody debris.<ref name=Kaufman/><ref>{{cite journal
column18: title=Characteristics of Canada lynx, ''Lynx canadensis'', maternal dens and denning habitat
column22: pages=605–608}}</ref> The home range of the expecting female shrinks and her activity at the den site increases.<ref name=Sunquist/>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: After a gestational period of two to three months, a litter of one to eight kittens is born.<ref name=Sunquist /> Lynx reproductive cycles and litter sizes have been observed to vary with prey availability; litter size would typically contract in years of snowshoe hare decline (along with high infant mortality rates), and increase when hares were abundant.<ref name=\"breitenmoser\">{{cite journal
column8: title=Predators of cyclic prey: is the Canada lynx a victim or profiteer of the snowshoe hare cycle?
column20: title=Lynx population dynamics in an untrapped refugium
column33: title=Lynx recruitment during a snowshoe hare population peak and decline in southwest Yukon
column45: abbr=on}} at birth, and initially have grayish buff fur with black markings. They are blind for the first 14 days, and [[weaning
column46: weaned]] at 12 weeks. Most births occur from May to July. Kittens leave the den after about five weeks, and begin hunting at between seven and nine months of age. They leave the mother at around ten months, as the next breeding season begins, but do not reach the full adult size until around two years old. Female offspring typically settle in home ranges close to their mothers and remain in contact with them for life, while male offspring move far from their mother's range. Females reach sexual maturity at ten months, although they often delay breeding for another year, whereas males reach maturity at two or three years. Canada lynxes have been reported to live for up to 16 years in wild, though most do not make it beyond 10 years; in captivity the lifespan may be as long as 27 years.<ref name=Sunquist /><ref name=Hunter/>

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: [[File:Young Lynx spotted west of Drayton Valley Ab - panoramio.jpg
The Canada lynx occurs predominantly in dense [[Taiga
1984-2003 Indo-Pakistani territorial cla: boreal forest]]s, and its range heavily coincides with that of the snowshoe hare. Canada lynxes generally avoid open areas despite good prey availability; they face difficulty surviving in heavily logged areas and agricultural land, though they can thrive well in deforested areas which have been left to regenerate for 15 years or more. In the past, the lynx occurred from the northern United States (in 24 States), possibly up to the [[Rocky Mountains]] in [[New Mexico]], to the [[tree line]] in the Arctic through coniferous forests in Alaska and Canada. The lynx continues to occur in most of Alaska and its erstwhile range in Canada. In the United States, the lynx occurs in the  [[Blue Mountains (Pacific Northwest)
column3: Blue Mountains]], [[Cascade Range]] and southern Rocky Mountains, [[Great Lakes region]] and [[New England]]. The lynx has been successfully reintroduced in [[Colorado]], where it had become extinct in the 1970s. Canada lynxes have been recorded up to an elevation of {{convert

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: A Canada lynx was shot near [[Newton Abbot]] in the United Kingdom in 1903 after it attacked two dogs. The animal remained unidentified at the time and was preserved by [[Bristol Museum and Art Gallery]], and was finally identified in a 2014 study. The researchers concluded that it had probably been captive for some time, perhaps as an [[exotic pet]] or part of a travelling menagerie, but may have survived for a substantial period after escaping. They considered it \"the earliest recorded example of an exotic cat on the loose in the UK\".<ref>{{cite journal
column16: title=Multidisciplinary investigation of a ‘British big cat’: a lynx killed in southern England c. 1903
column25: title='Big cat' Canada lynx was on the loose in UK in 1903
column31: title=That 'British big cat' called England's Loch Ness Monster? Its legend was fuelled by Canadian lynx, study says
column38: title=British big cat theory gets bump from lynx link

column4: Canada lynxes are trapped for their fur.]]

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: Canada lynxes are trapped in specific periods or seasons for fur trade in most of Alaska and Canada; hunting seasons and quotas are set based on population data. Even without regulations in place, the lynx-hare cycles and the distribution of the lynx have remained unaffected over the last century. In eastern Canada the lynx is threatened by competition with the [[eastern coyote]], whose numbers in the region have rose in the last few decades. Habitat loss is the main threat in the [[contiguous United States]], while trapping is a relatively insignificant cause of mortality. Hybridization between Canada lynxes and bobcats has been reported in the southern periphery of the range, and does not appear to be a threat to Canada lynxes.<ref>{{cite journal
column4: title=Canada Lynx-Bobcat (''Lynx canadensis × L.rufus'') hybrids at the southern periphery of lynx range in Maine, Minnesota and New Brunswick
column13: title = Hybridization between Canada Lynx and bobcats: genetic results and management implications

→‎Views,safe,Esszet,"{{Short description: The Canada lynx is abundant over its broad range, and is not significantly threatened by its legal use in the international fur trade since more than two centuries. Therefore, the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources]] (IUCN) classifies the Canada lynx as [[Least Concern]]. However, populations are relatively lower in the southern half of the range and are protected from killing for fur trade. The lynx is listed as Endangered in [[New Brunswick]] and [[Nova Scotia]].<ref name=iucn/> On March 24, 2000, the [[US Fish and Wildlife Service]] (USFWS) issued its Final Rule, which designated the Canada lynx a Threatened Species in 14 contiguous United States.<ref name=\"FedReg\">{{cite journal
column3: title=Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Plants; Determination of Threatened Status for the Contiguous U.S. Distinct Population Segment of the Canada Lynx and Related Rule
column9: publisher=Department of the Interior, Fish and Wildlife Service}}</ref> In 2005, the USFWS demarcated six major areas for revival where lynx populations had been reported in the past two decades: northern Maine and [[New Hampshire]], northeastern Minnesota, northwestern Montana and northeastern [[Idaho]], the [[Kettle River Range]] and the \"Wedge area\" between the [[Kettle River (Columbia River tributary)
column12: Washington]], the northern Cascade Range of Washington, and the [[Greater Yellowstone]] area of [[Wyoming]], Montana and Idaho.<ref name=iucn/> By 2010, after an 11-year effort, the lynx had been successfully reintroduced into Colorado. The initial introduction was in the [[San Juan Mountains]] in southwestern Colorado, but self-sustaining populations were established throughout the south-central Colorado Rockies as far north as [[Summit County, Colorado
column14: title=Success of the Colorado Division of Wildlife’s lynx reintroduction program
column21: publisher=Colorado Parks and Wildlife}}</ref> A 2012 study showed that numbers have improved in the northeastern United States;<ref>{{cite report
column36: publisher=Maine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife Research and Assessment Section
column37: location=Maine}}</ref> however a 2008 study showed lynx populations were not doing well in Washington due to [[habitat fragmentation]]. A 2017 study reported increasing numbers in many areas in the United States.<ref>{{cite report
column39: title=Species Status Assessment for the Canada lynx (''Lynx canadensis'') Contiguous United States Distinct Population Segment. Version 1.0
column43: publisher=Contiguous United States Distinct Population Segment
column44: location=Colorado}}</ref> In January 2018, the USFWS declared that the Canada lynx no longer needed special protections in the United States following measures to preserve their populations, and their \"Threatened\" status may be revoked in the future.<ref>{{cite news
column46: title=US says snow-loving lynx no longer need special protection
